reviewText: This is one of the best online strategy games with a great combination of strategy, tactics and politics, but (and this is where I agree with so many of the other reviews) the balance of the game is so extraordinarily in favor of the buying-system it is basically unplayable without spending a lot of money.\n\nThe problem is that there is no limit on the usage of the cards in the game. The more cards you have, the more troops you have, the faster they move and the stronger they are. You win by spending money -period-

reviewText:
Ah, Bothold Kingdoms.
Because people play using bots and dual accounts so I made a funny! :D
Okay whatever, I fire myself! I have fired myself.

Stronghold is like a lot of pay2win/free2play games built on the shoulders of a franchise that used to be great.
The original games were about you building a castle while surviving all sorts of nasty things trying to rip your castle down and harm your villagers.

Kingdoms takes that concept to the next level! Now you have to defend against other humans trying to attack you and you get to attack them too! It's great fun. Yeah that's right, I said fun.
Where it falls apart is that as is the norm for games of these types everything takes a very long time to build or  do...Unless you are willing to pay cash money.
Paying gives you an insane advantage over your fellow human players...At first! You see these games are played out in 'seasons' and seasons are about 4 months so if you don't join the choo-choo train immediately at the start of the season then the boundries have been drawn, alliances between players made and attacking anybody will get your castle DESTROYED!

So the thing you want to do in a PvP game, which is participate in PvP, you can't do because when your castle is destroyed it can take you either lots of months and the season will be over or cost you lots of real life cash so pick your poison.
Outside of the PvP you get to build your kingdom. That's, fun? I guess? You get to pick where a garden goes? And you get to plant some quarries? Yay? Yeah the city building is shallow and boring but you will spend most of your time doing that firstly because you need too since you need the resources to actually build your castle and secondly because you very rarely get to attack players due to them all banding together to rub out anyone who opposes their rulership.

While that is true to history there are plenty of better games that are historically accurate and FUN. The PvP gimmick is fun when you get to partake in it but the rest of the experience is boring or financially costly.

Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needs
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

reviewText:
After more than 400 hours on steam and at least 500 hours out of steam, I can write a review.

This is one of the most interesting games I've ever played. I hate it and love it at the same time.

Community is friendly towards new players, especially when you find someone from your country. They are willing to help, by giving you resources, tips on how to defend, what troops to use etc. Gameplay is good, a bit slow at start, but good.

But, I still cannot recommend it, because it is P2W game. People who buy cards and tokens will absolutely destroy all others. Freeroamers can survive for some time if they work together, but eventually they'll crack. I was in an really good and friendly faction where no one was buying cards, and we held for some time. Then we declared war on p2w guys. We had sent about 50 timed attacks on one village and we lost, because he was using cards to defend. After that they just devastated our faction.

Apart from that, game is really addictive and fun, but P2W aspect ruined it. Yes I am still playing it, and I can't tell you why, because I don't know myself.

Don't let this game to eat your soul, you will lose it forever.

reviewText:
Im going to save you a lot of time.

The game has leadership roles where you control a province or a county etc and tax below you, but youl never get to anything besides a parish (a couple people and some repeat inactives who dont count)

There are groups of people who use outside communication and know eachother from repeatedly playing over and over. They spend a bunch of money and put one of their people in, in pretty much every area... and you will never be accepted into their group, its not as inclusive as something like Evony was years ago when I played that, the leadership communicate outside the game and they use the in game system to exclude everyone else.

So you will never be of any consequence unless you spend a ton of money for recognition from other players.. and even then, its a total waste... youl join a group, that group will be made just for people like you.. to exclude you from leadership or any decision making, you wont even hear this stuff talked about, it takes a long time and several games before you realize that every group you join dies off by outside forces you were told to keep your nose out of and that even if you see a massive problem thats about to destroy the whole group of hundreds of people, no one will listen and they will turn on you if you try to help them... the other thing is, you begin to realize that every single group at its head is composed of disgusting people, they are terribly selfish and arrogant, intolerable as company or companions. The scum really does rise to the top, in this game.

All they want is for you to shut up and to be their slave, it really is like a feudal government system where if you dont know anyone in power right now, youre just going to be a slave for those who do.

Really, find a different game, the new worlds that start are almost immediately taken over by these types of people I talk about.. extremely arrogant and unskilled wallet warriors abusing cheesy mechanics and exclusionary tactics.

I also dont have 5000 hours.. and its a game where you are supposed to leave it running almost all the time to keep watch on whats happening.

reviewText:
I'll skip listing personal experiences and simply offer a quick list of pros and cons.

Pros:
- Throwback to Stronghold Crusader's glory days.
- Brilliant combination of casual Farmville and more modern RTS games.
- Endless depth.
- Strategy genre enthusiasts will be amused.

Cons:
- Obvious freemium business model. FireFly is apathetic to its drawbacks.
- Plan to play with family? Don't. You'll need to spend significant amounts of money to interact in-game, aside from joining the same faction and/or engaging in chain messages.
- FireFly doesn't screen for alt accounts. As long as they get their money, players are essentially free to do whatever they please, which leads to an awful lot of treachery and deception (in turn offering unfair advantages).
- Bans and suspensions are extremely infrequent. One player, reported by me, spammed several parish message boards with profanity, hate speech, and other vulgar material. He hasn't missed a day since.
- This game takes an inane amount of time to progress and is far too reliant on cash investment or alliances for sustainability.
- Speaking of alliances, players will find themselves thrust into the middle of warring factions or houses early on, unless they are fortunate enough to align themselves with well-off, high-ranking neutral players (who are far and few between).
- Politics can be fun, but it ultimately leads to drama and senseless wasting of time. You think Facebook is dramatic? Try SHK on for size.
- As each World progresses into a new Age, those worlds waste away into agonizing oblivion, later to be controlled by players who were previously shunned or spent far too long on the bottom rung and now desire to be worshipped.

After investing over 3,600 hours into this game, I feel qualified enough to offer a resounding No" to the question of whether or not I would recommend this game. While I cannot deny the amount of fun I've had
recommended: the bad most assuredly outweighs the good. If you have ample cash to spend
hoursPlayed: time to invest

reviewText: Stronghold Kingdoms is without doubt a complex, unique and interesting game, mostly due to the wide range of interaction possibilities between players, that usually become more and more important the more you get into the game. But is it also a good game, that I would recommend to my friends and such? We will see.\n\nWhen starting as a new player you will mostly be excited about all the cool researches that you can unlock, about the ranking up and village polishing, that will keep you busy and entertained at the same time. The game does quite well at that, and manages to introduce you into all the different aspects one after another, which keeps you motivated without overdemanding you. However, it can be said that the longer you play, that these things become less and less important. Researching and ranking up will become slower and slower and less interesting, and you will most likely start to see the computer generated castles and attacks more as an annoyance, than as a welcome gameplay element. reviewText:
This game, this game is so much fun to play if you've got time to waste. It's like farmville on crack.
The thing is, it's ridicously unbalanced. Cards that can be bought give you significant advantages.
Probably one of the biggest being able to manage your villages while youre not online.

The thing is, if you don't pay, you really dont get to play.

The boosts (cards) in this game that people buy give people an unbalanced benefit.

XP boosts (so you can expand faster and have more power)
Build time reduction (no joke, castles can take weeks of real time to build)
A que, (yeup you can only build one thing at  time if you dont pay)
peasant management while youre not in game. (basically peasants come in at set intervals depending on happiness, they're either assigned to your army or a vacant building to do a job, however you have to do this manually if you're not paying thus peasants tend to build up while you're not playing)

there's probably more that i'm missing but these ones are probably the most noteable.
I've seen people who have bought cards who grow 3-4 times faster than i can.

You can get cards for free...at times, but those cards will run out fast, and if you're not acquiring new ones you will fall behind.

I have over 700 hours in this game, and yet i cant recommend it.
voteText: 78 of 87 people (90%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Over 2000 hours played so stuck with it more than many, enjoyed the empire building aspect for some time, until vacation mode* (ability to protect your village from attack and disable all your production while you're away for work, school, sick, etc) was taken away and game became increasingly impossible to prevent complete destruction of all work due to extremely broken / exploited game mechanics.  (*You cannot use vacation mode unless you pay to use it -vacation mode is temporary, so you must have an active Coin to use it, and Coins cost RL cash.)

Each new age brings with it changes which further break and increase the damage that can be caused by the game breaking exploits, making it easier and easier for players to lose all spent cash in an instant to any one player using the exploits.  Every building, resource, and almost all actions take time, and all of these can be lost from the heavily unbalanced system of pvp.

There is zero positive admin activity and the fact that you can lose all work overnight with zero recourse, I would not recommend spending time, or money, on this game.

It's a pay to win, lose everything instantly (including the money you spent on the game) while you sleep, soulless game that if you spend any length of time on, can be lost within an hour.  There is next to zero game balance and all ingame work is destructible.

It is World of Tanks Gold ammo but FAR worse.  Card packs are temporary, and buffs are even more so, next to none lasting more than 23 hours.  The towns or armies they are used on can be taken out of the game, and there is no lasting aspect of the game except technology, gold, and honor, which leads to only one long-term plan for pvp, which is griefing using the aforementioned broken and easily exploitable ingame mechanics.

If the game was re-balanced to provide permanent cards you bought, but used cool-downs instead of just disappearing, then this game might be worth TRYING.

I do not recommend this game.


If you like this game, or want to like this game, I would recommend Clash of Clans app.  It's easily more fun than any one of the seconds in the over 2000 hours I've played Stronghold Kingdoms, and hasn't cost me anything.

reviewText:
This game has the worst 'community' of any game I've ever played and one of the most blatantly Pay-to-Win...
though it might not be as obvious to new players.

Basically you can buy expendable cards that serve like ammunition in the form of massive buffs or just straight-up instant repair, build, or troop recruitment.  Not only does real money buy you power & time, there's no cooldown or limit on how MANY cards you can play. It may be an incredibly expensive P2W but there are no restrictions on how far your wallet can take you other than how deep it is.

At top of that, they keep making new servers, spreading the playerbase thinner and thinner because the big spenders like to buy their way into world domination ASAP in new worlds, so the devs feed the wallet-warriors what they want while every other reasonable person has to suffer.

STAY THE HELL AWAY FROM THIS GAME.

I see innovation here - a lot of it. I see opportunities to play stronghold like never before, with an MMO idea all taking place on a large map where cooperation and diplomacy are key to victory in the world of thousands of players all with their own individual strongholds they too are building. The game still has all the customization that stronghold offered you as well, placing the walls, towers, gatehouses, moats, spikes, and more all wherever you want to. It also gives you the freedom to train and manually deploy your own troops both defensively in your castle and/or offensively to siege another. reviewText:
Stronghold Kingdoms is a possibly one of the most P2W games I have EVER played almost to the point that it becomes  hilarious. Let me explain.

I played the game across 4 game worlds have hundred of hours and spent the £6 it takes to get the 2 free cards a day. I feel this isn't too unreasonable for what is effectively a glorified browser game(that runs through it's own launcher). However I couldn't be more wrong.

It seems in each world in SHK there are literally a handful of hyper elitist, epeen obsessed, ego ♥♥♥♥♥s that have paid hundreds if not thousands of actual currency to roflstomp everyone who hasn't bowed down instantly to them. You can't defend against this level of P2W you just accept 'oh my village and castle i took a month to create will be gone in 1 second and have to start over'.

But don't just take my word for it, download the game and look in most of the worlds you will see about 85% of them are totally dead ruled by above described players. Firefly gets around this by creating a new world every now and then so the p2w can continue.

The carding P2W system allows you to for example: get to top rank of a new world in roughly 30 minutes (this takes months if you are 100% F2P), repeatedly raise a maximum sized army instantly, boost speed across the map to ridiculous levels, oh and gain totally unrestricted amount of in-game resources.

The Devs don't appear to care about the level of p2w as, as I understand the game is run by a small team. At the end of the day, why actually put any effort into creating a  fair game when you can sit back and let a few whales pay your salaries right SHK devs?

On a plus side the game still has the unique art style that made the early Strongholds great, but then this isn't surprising as most of this game has been ripped straight out of those early titles.

To summaries I haven't written this review in a moment of rage, more of sadness that yet another once great game studio that brought us great titles back in the day such as Stronghold 1, Crusades and Stronghold 2 has descended into the excrement of the F2P P2W market. I'd say the devs should take a good long look at themselves, as Firefly does have the history and potential to make good old school (almost indie?) games.

Edit: 23.04.2016

Just to update this review, I decided to try this game again to see if anything had changed and if my review was still relevant. Needless to say it has got even worse.

I played a totally peaceful role helping players where I could and not getting involved in any of the faction dramas that generally happen at the start of a new world.

By day 10 I have been deleted from the game world with no warning by a player that has paid a lot of money to get to almost top rank already  (only day 10 remember).

On asking him why he did this I was greeted by a torrent of offensive language and general elitism about he can because he paid" and how anyone who hasn't spent the amount of money he has in the game is garbage. I believe in psychological fields this is a classic case of a real world inferiority complex manifesting in an online environment.

As I said in my original review the devs seem fine with this level of pay to win
date: which in turn encorages these types of nasty individuals to group together.\n\nSo I still do not reccommend anyone try this game. Unless of course you like to make up for failings in your life by spending ludicras amounts of money in online games for self gratification no one else is willing to give you in the real world."

reviewText:
I will make a review with neggative and positive items so every reader can make his own opinion.

Firstly, we have to keep in mind that his game is a Free To Play so you will find a cash-shop that every F2P game have. This cash-shop gives a significative advantage: 1.- Premium token (you can move buildings, auto trade, auto scout, auto attack IA, auto recruit, give resources, troops or monks to a player that shares your IP, a global view of your villages) & 2.- Card packs (militarly, production, with different lvls with differents cost). With premium token you can have a proper manage of everything (I use premium only for buildings, auto recruit and global view of villages) but I don't spend money at card-pack because are expensive.

Card-Packs are used to make insta-armies, insta villages, insta resources, insta everything (even castle defences, reserachs, rank,...) When a player takes a lot of time to reach Crown Prince, there is a heavy carder that ranks to crown prince with full villages full armies full research and everything in a few days. I can talk more about this theme but there is a better choice than keep reading me: Go to stronghold kingdoms and enjoy reading all types of cards.

So, there is nothing more to add about pay-theme. However, there is a topic that a lot of people don't like: How Staff manages the multi-accounting/sharing IP (not the same as multi-accounting)/etc. I have met a lot of friends in real life that got banned just because they shared IP a few times (House-LAN-party, for example) so FireFly starts to follow you. In case you get again the conflict of IP-Sharing, they start to ban you (24, 48h, 72h,...until it reachs to perma-ban). In my opinion, there is no way (at least have 100% prove) that one player has multi-accounted. And not all multi-accounting players are banned because one friend got bored from this game and he create intentionally 5 accounts to farm FP and makes a mess in different servers. He claimed that he was multi-accounting and ask FireFly to ban him, however, he did not got ban (at least perma ban).

In my opinion, that is all about what I dislike of FireFly. There are other things as the number of worlds, or how FireFly organizes different stuff...but I don't think that is relevant. About the positive stuff I can clearly say that there is a big bunch of them:

We can start with the experience of every MMO: It's a massive game online where you share experiences with other players & compete each other in order to be at first place and satisfy your Ego (normally, there are players that have different objectives). This game doesn't make you play only for the main goal (win era), you can make your own objectives (of course, with no monetary prize) like being the most farmer, most fighter, most diplomatic, most roler (I have found different groups that roled in SHK: Extremist religious people, pacifist people who like to feed players, ...).

In addition, SHK have plenty tones of features as research tree (It gives you a lot of strategies and different ways to grow), castle design (is the only game about strategy and mmo that let's you design your own castle), armies design (mix the number of troops and how to send them), village layouts, strategy to produce, divide work & be better than others, etc...


In conclusion, I don't recommend this game because his creepy-staff & high use of Cash-shop to finance his project and disbalance the game. They have improved a lot since Alpha but they have to improve a lot more if they want to increase their population. I want to keep clear that this profile only have 10 hrs because I use the stand-alone version of SHK.

My nickname in game is Usurf Pieschafados.

reviewText:
First of all, this game is NOTHING alike the other Stronghold games. It is a strategic castle/village building game, with combat, trading, gathering ressources, monks, etc, in a real-time large world to play on. You have to wait for your buildings to be completed and your army takes a long time to get to other castles to attack so expect a less action-filled gameplay!

My steam time is inacurate, i've only played the game downloaded directly from the website, I was rank 20 on 2 worlds. While it was fun and entertaining for a month, it quickly became tedious and well... Keep reading.

Not only that, but it is one of the most P2W game ever created in my opinion. If you pay alot of money, you can get an unlimited amount of cards that can repair your castles, spawn troops, make your troops 3-6x faster, almost everything is possible with those cards. If you want to get them without paying, it takes a lot of time and to get a steady amount of cards you need to have purchased Crowns ( Real money currency. ).

You can simply win a war by ''Carding'', yes, it actually is a term! Credit Carding pretty much. Otherwise, the game could have been fun longterm, leading your House to victory via economy, war, diplomacy or monks!

reviewText:
Along side the pay to win comments, and the broken mechanics and all that, I will give you my experience first hand.

I figured out a great way to make use of the economy through trade early in the game to help get some extra resources to boost my production in various areas. I was accellerating quite well in the game for the first week. Then you get to a point where things start to take time and a little more strategy of what to build and upgrade based on a focus you want to persue. This I was happy with because it makes sense, you can't just major in everything and expect to go far sooner. So I went into military while prepping for religeous expansion. Once again, I was progressing along very nicely.

Probably a couple of months went by of dedicated play time (logging every day). I was making smart attacks, gaining honor, rebuilding my troops to always maintain 200 defending troops in my castle, and another 200-300 attacking AI for honor. My castle had a moat around the whole area, traps set, and maxed balista towers as well as turret towers, along side my 200 archers. I had two sets of walls that circled my village for enemies to get through, the walls were 3 layers thick, and I had large/grand towers all around as well. Also started to build into religion as I was able to max out my military.

2 months of work that built me up to this, and one day I get on to find out I was attacked for the first time. What was I attacked with? 2 captains who were obviously maxed out, and I think 20 pikes. None of them died because the captains apparently can heal them as well as make them go incredibly fast, as well as boost their dmg so they basically ran through the moat (which usually takes about 3-5 seconds for an enemy to fill), took down both sets of walls in a matter of 3 seconds, ran over my few pikes in my village and won the fight and looted my village. The entire attack took about 5-6 seconds after I spent about a month building my bloody castle.

So what's the point of spending all of that time building when all someone has to do is max their captains upgrades (only a few upgrades to do), go in and take down a fully constructed castle in a matter of seconds? The only thing that protected me from being attacked again was an ally sending a monk to my castle and giving me protection for 24 hours or something. All that work put into protecting my village, and someone sends in 22 guys that just destroys me. That doesn't make any sense. Thus, I deleted the game.

That's my rant/review of this game. Choose to support it if you will, or force them to smarten up their mechanics and balancing system. Because in reality, this is a GREAT strategy game. But I will not play it again with crap like that happening.

reviewText:
I love this game. Building your own mini empire across several settlements, setting up trade routes between them, sending out hordes of units to assault other people's castles are all fun, and getting big enough to be tipped into a faction and start politicking is also fun. People are on 24/7, building and plotting each other's demise, and it inspires an incredible sense of dedication to checking in over the course of the day and making it a part of your life. Things happen slowly, but the decisions you make are always interesting.

That said, the game has two hard currencies: time and money. The more you're on, and the more your allies are on, the more you can strategize and wage a 24/7 war against whoever. There is a way to build an efficient and collaborative war machine, and doing things besides playing this game are not it. Even if you do dedicate your waking existence to the game--and there are definitely enough people who do so that it matters--you can still be outspent by people with really deep pockets that are filled with real world currency, who spend it on thigns that give them free resources, production boosts, and movement boosts. I don't think it's possible for a faction that is 100% dedicated but doesn't spend a dime to overcome a faction that is 100% dedicated and has a few people spending $10. If anyone reading this knows otherwise, I'd love to hear about it.

So I'm split. The game is great fun, but only until you run into a group of players who have more time and real world money than you. Once that happens, they crush the ♥♥♥♥ out of you and take your settlement and all of the buildings and resources you accumulated. Once you lose all settlements, it's back to square one. You're given a fresh hamlet to build up and inevitably have raided, and it becomes clear that all you're doing is producing a series of feeder farms for the upper echelons. And that's cool and all, but I get enough of this kind of ♥♥♥♥ in the real world.

reviewText:
Playing all of the Stronghold games, I was excited to see what Kingdoms had to offer.  Putting your castle on a real world map and playing with/against other people has its appeal.  Playing it, it lost the appeal rather fast.  After feeling disconnect from my village, town, parish, and the game, I have yet to go back it again.  This may be for others that like this, but as a fan of the Stronghold series, and a fan of stratagy games, this one fell short of both.

Pros:
- Real world map
- Multiplayer
- Free to Play

Cons:
- No real time castles seges (MMO not an RTS)
- Village and Castles disconnect occures
- Allows non stratigic castle overbuild (Just place a lot of one good thing to win)
- Never got pulled into the Kingdom's community (if it exists)
- Feels like a combersom single player game

reviewText:
I approached this game with some hope that it would be a decent replacement for Lord of Ultima. Not only was this hope squashed, the game itself is quite poor and nothing more than a cash grab.

I fully expect all FTP games will have some cash incentives involved, it's the nature of the beast. People need to eat, pay their bills and try to have a normal life. I have no problems paying for premiums in a FTP that is actually good. This is something at a much higher level that shows itself as soon as playing through the tutorial. At least in this regard it is out in the open.

All I can say is that you can see for yourself, but I would save you a considerable waste of time.

reviewText:
I used to play this game quite obsessively as the amount of time you are on the game greatly affects your perfomance ratings. It isn't the sort of game you can take a long break from (hours not days).

Unfortunately due to this fact this game has several 'pay to win' points which completely ruins the whole idea of this being a free to play game which hasn't changed with any of the expansions or patches.

Don't get me wrong, this isn't a 'add feature' payment system this is a 'massively skip ahead the free people' system.

If you've got money to throw at a game and time on your hands i'd recommend this, otherwise stay clear.

reviewText:
PROS
+Trading/Merchants/Constantly evolving economy
+Fun watching replays of your Troops Battle
+Sieges
+AI
+Build your Villages and Castles
+Factions and Global War
+Real Map of the World to Battle On
+Strategy/Planning your Attacks

CONS
-Pay 2 Win/Pay 2 Play
-If your not Premium, you have ALOT of restrictions...
-Pay 2 Win Cards.
-Very Slow paced Game
-You can easily be wiped out by a Pay 2 Win Player or a Group/Faction
-Be Randomly attacked at any Time (Day or Night irl) and have most or all of your resources stolen... or even just losing your Village/Castle all together.
-Researching/Unlocking is a very... very... very slow process
-No Real Time Battles, can't strategize while in a Battle, AI does it for you.
-Can't attack Merchants/Traders/Scouts/Monks/Anything that is traveling on the Map.
-Can't intercept and attack enemy armies before they reach your Castle.

reviewText: If you are a Stronghold fan and like the typical browser-based RTS games that are around these days, then you'd like this game. The persistence and MMO-style of this game means that PvP greifing will get you down, but it still has some of that Stronghold feel. The city vs. castle vs. parish castle vs. region castle can get a bit confusing, and the parish/region mechanics make it near impossible for a non-faction aligned player to have any influence. While it does have some Stronghold flair, it suffers from too many MMO/Browser game limitations.

reviewText:
I have to say that I only played this game thanks to a former friend, and to be honest...I'm not that impressed with it.
This game is above all a time consumer, like most free to play strategy games.  It is both a time consumer, and involves a lot of politics.  For most people, this is okay; for the casual gamer who likes to spend a few minutes every day managing a castle and speaking with people in your parish and your house when you get higher up it works out alright.  It can have its fun moments, and equally its pretty jerkish moments with other players, as regardless of what you're doing or how you are playing there are still many other players out there on your world that are playing at the exact same time as you are, and some take this game hardcore.

This game...is too slow.  Way too slow.  I can see why; it's meant to keep players engaged in a game about castles with other people.  I can appreciate a game being slow for the sake of realism.  But if I'm going to be gathering resources, building a city, constructing a castle, or making soldiers I would like the luxury of designing everything in the glory of realtime thanks to technology.  I'm used to playing games like Age of Empires, Starcraft, Supreme Commander and the like, where playing too slow gets you booted, so when I'm forced to go immensely slow just to see my fifth or sixth pig farm get built to feed my many cities, I got a bit batsh-erhem...I go a bit wonky.

I got as far as Prince before I gave up on this game.  My house was unlucky enough to be one of the lesser houses on the winning side, and knowing my luck another house would not pick up me or my faction due to the low priority of both my parish and my region.  So, I bade my party farewell and offed my castles, and have lived the better for it.  Too bad I'm not going to be getting all those hours back I should have spent studying for college.

reviewText:
I wish I could recommend this, but I can't. Not only I have spent over 800 hours on Steam launcher, but I also have atleast 1000 hours on launcher that I downloaded from SHK's site. This game has a lot of potential to be something greater, but all that good falls with the classic F2P game situation, Pay to win... This game has given me some nice experiences, but most of time I've spent has gone wasted with losing all hard work, destroyed by the ones who pay loads of cash.

So I've listed some Pros and Cons, here we go...

-Pros-

+ Four tech trees that give some variety, though most likely your forced to pick Military sooner or later...

+ Graphics are made in that old Stronghold style, I personally like it.

-Cons-

- P2W... Hardest carders spend thousands of euros on new servers.

-You can't place village buildings wherever you want if you want them to be effective.

-Spend hours building something, just to find it captured or razed by some carder, while you were sleeping. The reasons are often random.

-Kinda same as previous one. Theres no way to just farm alone... Neutrals are often captured or forced to join a side, OR BE RAZED.

Don't play this game, just dont... Too much time and money wasted on this... This would be perfect without the cards etc... I'd even pay monthly fee for a cardless version of SHK. *Sigh* It won't happen though.

reviewText: I joined right before a new world was going to open up. I had just enough time to get the basics down on an older world before switching to the new one on release. The race was on. It was thrilling and fun to level up as fast as possible and try to control the most land. As I ranked up and people began to forge alliances I began to talk to people. I soon learned that to the north, a man had spent THOUSANDS of dollars buying himself an amazing set of cities with good defenses. This is a pay to win game. I spent 90% of my time on this game for the next few weeks, and never got to the level that the man was at on Day 1. Other people caught up to me too, by paying money.\nIf you love pay to win games, have a lot of money to burn, and enjoy strategy games you'll love this game. The community is, for the most part, good, and it is enjoyable. Stay away if you don't want to pay.

reviewText:
Not recommended because it's pay to win. You can buy strategy cards which can boost your production, or instantly replenish your army, or instantly let you finish your research, or instantly lets you place buildings, etc. Paying players can rank up in minutes what non paying members would take months. The top players have spend thousands of dollars on this game. You will see these players in multiple servers, all joining together and taking the fun out of this game. SHK would be more fun and equal if it wasn't for these strategy cards. The devs needs to release a server without them.

Yes, I have played this game for months, why? Because I also had fun. You start peasant, with 1 town and no research, almost no gold and you rank up to crown prince with 15+ cities, a huge army and millions in gold. You can become a farmer and build and sell a huge amount of supplies, become a fighter and attack enemy players, or become a monker and use the power of faith to take out your enemies. You can all do it in this game.

As you rank you rank up you get to research new types of food, weapons, merchants, new unit types, buildings, or increase speed/capacity of existing units/production facilities. Your villages (and later villages) will start to grow, allowing you to sell more stuff and get richer. You will start by attacking and scouting wolf lairs, and as you grow stronger, with more advanced and stronger unit types, you can attack enemy castles.

Castle attacking is very basic. Just place your army and send the attack. It will then take several minuts to hours (depending on the distance) for your army to arrive. Battles are automatic and you will only see a battle report after the battle is finished. AI pathfinding can be a bit weird.

Players can play together and form factions. Several factions can join a house. Houses can form alliances and fight for control over the map. Sounds fun, but in most servers super alliances are quickly formed and then everyone farms, there is no fighting for control of the map. New players should join a new server, because older servers are pretty much dead and AI is too difficult to attack.

reviewText:
I played in one of the original four worlds of this game, many years ago. I will say that if you put time into it, this can be a fun game.

However, the game is a pay to win game that demands a lot of time, and punishes heavily for ignoring it, typically requiring even more money to recover from mistakes. Even if you do everything right, you will need money.

The communication required to successfully coordinate is staggering. I met people who literally backstabbed each  other, and showed so much distrust that they refused to play with each other anymore over a game. If you ever wanted to study how people act when a game has serious stakes, this is probably one of the games to do it.

If that sounds like a game for you, then go for it. However be aware that this game will require money, coodination skills (far beyond what MMO guilds demand),likely a voice chat server, and over a 100 people you can rely on.

Even if you do not plan to win the leaderboards, be aware that if someone wants, they can and will take over your villages. Even if you have nothing to do with a war, you will likely be taken over if you did not properly build your castle.


In Short: If you want a demanding pay to win game that is more about making friends, coordinating, and keeping people from wanting to kill each other, then this game is for you. Do not get sucked in.

reviewText:
I have played all the Stronghold Games, and this game is very addictive i've spent over 600 hours in this all together with this account, with my other steam account and out of steam. It's alot of fun but it is a PAY TO WIN game, and I've tried playing with and without paying in this game.

Stronghold Kingdoms took the Original Stronghold idea and made it into an online game,it is divided into five main areas:

Your Villages : Where you build up your economy, you make your population happy or angry by increasing the tax levels, the ammount of food they will receive and the ale they are allowed to the drink.These 4 factors will give you honor, which is used to conquer, pillage raze or plunder other player's villages. You can get more honor by making banquets.

Your Castles: Castles have always been a huge part of Stronghold games. Using the resources you get from improving your village you will be able to build huge castles to protect your economy and productivity. These castles can then be garrisoned by the troops you create, Either pikemen, archers, swordsmen or catapults.

The People Around you/ Houses: Having alot of players in the same game just pillaging each other until the last man standing wouldn't be much fun all the time, So the developers decided to create Houses, these are like Factions you join there are 20 houses in the game, Each house has a marshall that decides what the house should do next.
These houses devide into factions in the House which are controlled by high ranking members.

The best invasion I have ever seen was the Invasion of England which was controlled by House 1 in the Europe World, France(House 11), Spain(House 9) and Portugal(House 9) all decided to go against H1, in 1 day it was in shatters most of the players had been eliminated or just deserted they're House. It was truly an impressive feet.

Armies and Vassals: As you grow in the game you can decide to have liege lords ( Someone who will protect you from other people, send you resources and armies to defend yourself) and have vassals, in which case you do the same thing to the people you decide, Each vassal allows a maximum of 500 troops to be garrisoned in the village allowing the liege lord to have thousands upon thousands of men ready for an attack.

And Research: Research is a major factor in Stronghold Kingdoms because it allows the player to get a step ahead on other people, either in farming, military or industry.

It takes alot of time and efford to become powerful in stronghold kingdoms without Paying money.Took me about 100 days to become powerfull and that's going to stronghold every day to check up on what's going on.

And what made me angry as hell was seeing that in 5 days Using loads of money a player got to The max rank! 5 DAYS man!! What in the ♥♥♥♥!!
It just made all my effords seem meaningless. Therefore I do not recommend this game, it is a time waster Do not play this unless you want to spend large ammounts of your time and money.

reviewText:
Rise of The Wolf update has damaged this game, especially if you are relatively new.

I enjoyed the game when I first started, it was a very slow paced medieval city builder with custom designed castles and such. I spent my days gaining resources and slowly beefing up my stronghold and donating extra resources to my local parish capitol.

Days of doing this was quite relaxing, and the occasional Ai attack spiced things up. Seeing how well my newly made fortifications held up against 30, then 60, then 100, then 130 enemies was quite fun.

I also thought it was very cool getting to view battles between my parish and our enemy Ai, Pig. Large scale battles taking place every day while we fuel the parish with resources was amazing.

Then Rise of The Wolf happened.

All at once we had an enemy Siege camp, wolf dens, bandit camps, Pig and its castle of doom, and all of the associated negative morale. Pig for what ever reason appears to target my town exclusively, on top of daily sieges and bandit raids.

Within 3 days my forces had been reduced to 3 archers and 2 morale resulting in a single peasant every 12 hours, my food consumption was set to max to boost morale with very little effect and my taxes were already starting to drain what little gold reserve I had. Then I realize that no one is attacking Pig, the siege camp, or the bandits.. and it appears most of their aggression is focused towards me. Our parish apparently had been innactive for several days prior so help from them was a long ways off.

After speaking out in global chat, I found out that I am not the only one facing this scenario. The competent players are away or ignoring the enemies, while the weak and defenceless are destroyed by the new enemy spawn rate.


So, unless you know a strong player and can get cozy with them and their army, stay away until Rise of The Wolf is put to rest.

reviewText:
I'm only saying no, because I'm on the fence. If you've got the real-life money to support the in-game upgrades, then you're fine and you'll really enjoy the game, without, you're kinda ♥♥♥♥ed. For a 'free' game, it's not so free.
The whole game is in real-time, and that's ok. However, with every building you place, and every thing you research, it bumps up the time. No matter the type of building, or research option. Just adds minutes to the time. And that's not so bad, until it hits over 30 minutes and you haven't got the tokens to have a building and research queue.
So with this, it takes a long time to build up a decent, protected base with enough peasants to train a competent army to defend your stronghold. Problem with that is, you're a new player, and this is an online world. A lot of players will ignore rule 7 - don't be a ♥♥♥♥, and just attack you for the sake of attacking. For me, who is a slow learner, that just makes the game even harder and unfair. the 2 days worth of protection at the beginning is great, but I think that needs to be a week. In a week you an have a decent wooden defence line and a good-ish sized army (depending on how happy you keep the peasants) to protect your stronghold after the timer goes out.

Other than that, the user friendly-ness of the game is great, and I love the option that you get to keep the tutorial pages near by, in case you forget anything, then you an just turn it off when you're ready, and that's awesome. The graphics are alright, but since they're really simple, it doesn't lag your computer, which is a bonus if you run off wireless all the time like me.
I also like having the different tabs at the top, keeping everything seperated out and neat really helps you get to grips with the game.
So overall, I like the game and won't stop playing it, but I wouldn't recommend it. I'm just stubborn and miss being able to play the old Stronghold games.(Saving the money up for the complete pack though)

reviewText:
Stronghold Kingdoms is a very slow paced game that requires a lot of diplomacy with other players. It's a type of game that you leave on when you're browsing. I have played this game since early 2012 to late 2014. I really like the card system In Stronghold Kingdoms. The artwork is very nice, I really like it. Most of the content is reused from old Stronghold games but I still like it. The people I've met are very nice and friendly.

However, It was very fun when I played the game at first, I played it every day, it was very addicting and I spent a lot of hours in this game before I downloaded the Steam version. I downloaded the steam version more than a year later. I started playing on World 4 when the server was still 30 days old. The game just gets boring after a some hundred days where everyone has a high rank and the world becomes dull. I tried to like it in my last few hundred days playing but it just didn't work. Then I stopped playing at about day 800. People say this game is pay to win, I kinda agree. Things like premium token will give you progress faster in the game.

I have mixed feelings about this game. I like the Stronghold series. But I don't recommend this game. Because in long term playability, it kinda sucks. Stronghold Kingdoms might be enjoyable and fun at first, but in a year or several months, the World(server) will become dull. You'll need to play it every day or else you could lose all your progress, because if you have an enemy, they will try to wipe you out.

reviewText:
Although it is a fairly fun and exciting stratergy game, I have many problems with it.

The actually game play is very slow with building times and research times getting longer and longer each time you build or research something. The scouts take about half an hour (real time) to reach an item and return when it is not that far away from your kingdom or village.

Until about 10 minutes ago (from when I'm writing this), I was queueing things up like buildings and research items so I could leave the game to work for me. Now, I have to get premium coins to queue things. This means I have to check on everything more often and the game play is slow enough as it is.

Now I understand this is a Free to Play game so I would guess the company would put an option in to buy things with real money so they can get some money from it but when one of the achievements is to buy coins? It makes it a game I want to punch in it's metaphorical face.

I'm going to continue to play this game because I am determined to find a way to win without paying but don't start if you haven't already.

reviewText: Stronghold Kingdoms has some good ideas including an excellent village building system, interesting and balanced research tree and challenging castle building process. Although the game is free to play, it is impossible to be a strong player without purchasing coins and card points. The top players spend massive amounts of money to crush ordinary foes. Additionally, the game drags on for a very long time and soon grows stale. After a few weeks, the servers  largely empty out as most players get bored or are destroyed. Stronghold could be an excellent long term game with some improvements, but now it is a pay to win money machine.

I spent a lot of time playing and only got rekt by my own choice (quit).

Real lucky.  Dont play.

I will tell you that that this game is pay to win. There are many people that throw that phrase around, but this game is serious pay to win. Unashamed and unappoligetic.  If you can afford a constant stream of cards, like 200 dollars a month, you can stand up to any guild in the game and become almost invicible. Oh I logged off and you took a village of mine.  I just instantly took one of yours with a village that i had in protection and now i will instantly build the entire village and castle within seconds.  Worst case i lose everything and then drop in a bunch of charters and now I has free invulnerable time to take my time and build.   If you dont have those resources, your losses are catastrophic and final. Loosing a city for me is nothing, but  a few minutes while your loss was a month of painstacking grinding.

I will say that this game is very addicting, but not in a good way.  You become beholden to sitting in front of your computer and watching icons constantly moving across the map and trying to deciper if some bad icon will be coming your way soon or if you can help someone thats about to get killed.  I dont mind this, but you almost dont want to sleep as people will learn your ofline play time and jump you when you log out.  Also, if your opponents have more real money than you, they will almost always win.  I have been in massive guilds with 100s of people attacking a base and still not being able to take the castle because he can completely rebuild it within seconds. Even if you time all your attacks there is usually a few seconds that might cause the last attack to fail.  It is fun to play for a while, but like i said you will develop a nervous desperation to constantly be logged in and not want to do anything else.  Its not enjoyable either as you are constantly on the defensive or having to manage things.  Huge time sink.

Do not buy! Yes you can get cards by Trickling them in 1 a day and you can sell to buy better cards, but the shear amount of cards that your opponents will have and the amount of cards he can use within seconds makes the game completely unbalanced between the haves and the have nots.

reviewText: I played this for months many moons ago before it came to Steam. So much potential, wasted because it's completely P2W. The community was great. Everyone was very friendly and helpful and I enjoyed chatting with them all, but the tedious pace of the gameplay eventually wears you down. Eventually you actually start considering buying cards.....just about the time your sanity snaps back and you delete the game instead of wasting your hard earned cash.\n\nIf you like idle games, this may be fun for you. But you will never be able to keep up with people who pay for cards in this game, and the extremely slow pace will drive you nuts. Everything takes forever to happen in the game.  Cards are the only way to advance at more than a glacial pace, and they really are not worth it.

reviewText:
Stronghold Kingdoms is as much a game of politics as it is a game of Medieval warfare or simulation. The articulate politician will find himself advancing far more quicker than the warrior and it is not at all uncommon to find House Marshalls who have only razed a handful of players.

First I'd like to address the two foremost complaints about Stronghold kingdoms; Pay to Win and Multi Accounters

Mulits - Players controlling 2 or more accounts per game world.

The problem here is twofold and blame falls equally on both the players and Firefly. All too often I see a user on the forums calling for heads to roll after he reports a player suspected of cheating and nothing happens. The paranoid player would do well to remember that suspicious does not equal guilty and that Firefly will not disclose the outcome of any investigation to the player who filed the report.

If it appears nothing has been done it's likely because the investigation turned up nothing illicit and remember the more information you include in your report the more likely the accusation is to be investigated.

The other half of blame sits squarely upon Firefly's shoulders in my opinion due to the sheer ambiguity of the game rules. Time and time again I've had players coming to me with multiple accounts firm in their insistence that they weren't breaking any rules because they had premium tokens in play on both accounts".

Despite what anyone might say to convince you otherwise the above allegation is flat out untrue. Regardless of premium tokens
date:
players are only allotted one account per game world. All Firefly here has to do is update the game rules page to be less ambiguous in regards to the IP restrictions and premium players clause but they will not and this apathy towards one of the top complaints about Stronghold Kingdoms promotes the continued perpetuation of the myth that Firefly doesn't care and that they don't investigate informed allegations against suspected cheaters.


Pay To Win - The belief that to succeed at any level in Stronghold Kingdoms the player must spend liberal amounts of money to obtain their own virtual crown.

Pay to Win (or P2W) is a hotly debated topic in many 'Free to play' games and the same applies to Stronghold Kingdoms and there is no doubt that in this case it's a grey area for sure. But to answer whether or not the game is p2w one must first define what winning means to them and what winning means to Firefly.

For many players 'to win' is to beat another player in a one on one mano a mano fight. Providing both players are of the same skill level and neither receive any outside help there is no doubt that whichever of the two players spends more on the game will ultimately be the winner. There are just too many cards in the Stronghold Kingdoms deck that artificially boost combat stats such as army speed or the strength of castle structures and Firefly doesn't help the matter by continuing to introduce more powerful combat cards all the time.

Sure
recommended: the only players who use those aces are probably the top 0.5% but in worlds with dwindling playerbases those players hold the entire server at their collective whim.\n\nIn contrast
hoursPlayed: many experienced players realize that winning is actually more than a one on one fight and that loosing one battle doesn't mean the war is lost and that there are dozens
voteText: if not hundreds
helpfulPercent: of players participating on both sides of the conflict
votesHelpful: carder and non carder alike. This means that while you are going up against a house with spending players your house will likely have spending players of it's own which levels the playing field.\n\nFirefly's definition is similar to the above
votesTotal: Houses compete against one another to gain glory
votesFunny: ultimately eliminating all others houses to be the last one standing. That final House is considered the winner of that age and inducted into the hall of fame while their members all share in on the spoils of the victory which mostly consists of a few quest wheel spins
commentsCount: card packs
column16:
and new charges for their coat of arms.

This means that to 'win' Stronghold Kingdoms all one has to actually do is be a member of whichever house is left standing when the dust settles.

As you can now see the definition of winning in stronghold Kingdoms is actually quite subjective and by paying attention to ongoing house politics virtually anyone can achieve victory regardless of their financial status.

## Now that that's cleared up.... ##

Although my Steam time doesn't show it
column17: I have played Stronghold Kingdoms via the Standalone client for almost 3 years now and in that time I have been active in many roles. I'm currently on a sort of hiatus with Stronghold Crusader 2 gearing up for release.\n\nAnyways
column18: here's what I liked:\n\n+ First and foremost is the community
column19:
a game that pretty much coerces you into logging in every day lends itself to the establishment of long distance relationships that can become something like a second family to you.

+ 2D graphics invoke a nostalgic feeling in fans who have been with the Stronghold franchise from it's inception.

+ Freedom to design my castle as I please
column20: there is no generic 'castle' building that is placed with one click. You have to determine where each wall segment and Stone Tower will be built.\n\n+ Village building can be as simple or as intricate as you want
column21:
village buildings fit together much like a puzzle and those who take the time to optimize their village layout will enjoy increased production.

What I felt could be improved on:

- Battles aren't fought in real time
column22:
you play puzzle games by setting up your troops and letting the AI resolve it. The AI is quite predictable and stupid at times.

- The ingame chat system is so unintuitive it actually drives players away from the game.

- The entire card system requires too much micromanagement. For a game that requires more and more of your time as you grow having to juggle cards daily to stay competitive gets pretty old pretty quick.

- The formula used to generate AI castles needs to take the number of players in that parish into account
column23:
not only the rank of the players. It's a real kick in the head to get the strongest wolf castle in your parish every week when the only 3 villages there are yours.

What I'd like to see added in the future:

> Castles and villages merged into one design
column24:
this would mean that defensively strong players would have weaker economies and the inverse for economically strong players. This would encourage greater diversity in playstyle.

> Actual RTS battles that allow direct player control of the attacking armies and the defending garrison if the player so wished.

> More units
column25: especially siege units. Even the original Stronghold had twice as many units as there are currently in Stronghold Kingdoms.\n\nIn short
column27: I strongly recommend this game. It's probably the best free to play RTS on Steam at this moment
column28: and while the graphics hail from a previous decade they still retain the charm of the original Stronghold.\n\n- IGN DavidSpy"

reviewText: Stronghold Kingdoms is a griefer heaven; it's even more hardcore than Eve Online. You can spend months and hundreds of dollars building your villages and castles, then lose them all in a matter of minutes to someone else who spent even more months and thousands of dollars.\n\nNew players will find themselves losing everything they've built on a weekly basis to other players with forces so superior they won't even break a sweat. Unlike other hardcore games like Eve Online, your village can't run or hide. As soon as your newb shield" drops
date: your possessions go to feed whoever gets to steal them first.\n\nIf you're lucky
recommended: you'll end up next to someone willing to help you. That just means it will take slightly longer for you to lose all your stuff.\n\nWhy am I still playing even though I give it a NO recommendation? Because I don't care how many villages I lose as long as there's someone weaker than me

reviewText: I quit after about 30 minutes, This game is a typical mobile Pay-to-win, unlike what ZAM said (They were paid off or something). You start out with about 4 villagers, and each villager is super important, as they make buildings work, can scout for food, and be turned into military units. You get units by making the overall population happy. you do this by making more space, bribing them, or feeding them. But you can also just PAY REAL MONEY to increase your happiness, or PAY REAL MONEY to buy villagers, you can really just PAY REAL MONEY to do anything in this game, which is why it sucks hard.

reviewText: Well, when I first played this game a year ago, I loved it. It downloaded fast and was able to play in seconds. It was fun, exciting and good to play while doing something else. The beginning was rough, it seemed like impossible to get to an acceptable rank. Luckily I was invited to join a group of other nearby lords who later in the game invited me to the House. When I was first invited the game went smoothly because of all the support my allies gave me. Soon after I was a target for an enemy House. Of course this House member payed to get insane amount of cards, tokens and etc., and then I got destroied. I didn't pay into this game, but now I see I should. There is such a huge advantage against people who pay-to-win. I seriously don't agree with ZAM, stating it is not a pay-to-win". It is.\n\nAgain I tried playing again later down the year and of course the same thing happened on a different server. I thought this was ridiculous and a joke. I quit and wouldn't even bother playing with the new update. 4/10."

reviewText:
Okay, so SHK wanted players to give feedbacks and review of the game so here it goes.


First off to those that does not know the game, it takes a long long long time for ages to pass on different worlds and they never seem to be ending soon so I will give some feedbacks on the future of the game and for future new ages(which desperatly needs to warp up and end really really soon.

Here is a link if you want to go check that feedback out(this is mostly just for the vaterans :D ): Link is in progress, sorry.

Intro: As for the game itself, well reviewing this kind of game is going to be a tough one since its really different from any other game I had ever played. To keep it short, SHK is a game somewhat like trivian or tribal-wars which are real-time based (Build your kingdom type)strategy games. Of cause SHK is much more complex and beautifully complicated than any other MMO out there. Just know that these kind of games will suck in all of your time and all the beautifully built villages that you have put so much time and effort can easily be taken away over night. Yes that's right, over night! But that is not so much of a bad thing because thats what makes the game very interesting and complex. Yes you can lose your villages but the honor, gold, faith points and rank will remain the same even if you lose all your villages. Keep in mind these such points are the important part of the game, not villages, so that is a good thing that you dont lose your progress.

Gameplay / Graphics As for the gameplay, this is a straight forward build your kingdom and expend it at all costs. It can be time consuming, very very much so. I had played this for over 3 years on and off and I can never get on top of the leaderboards yet. Also, there are groups(factions and houses) where you join and fight for that particullar group. These houses either ally themselves with one another or declare war on each other because the main goal of the game is to win the glory race. The gloary race can be won if a house can eliminate all other houses thus the last house is ultimately the winner of the race. You get big rewards if you win the race that can be used to give some perks on the world you are playing and on every other worlds.

Graphics on this game is taken almost 100% taken out of the original Stronghold Crusader" game that came out over a decade ago but thats not a bad thing either since that was one of the best games ever created
date: ever. They did improve on the quality of the game though so its really well done. This is a stretegy game not a 4K graphic driven game so graphics doesn't really matter.\n\nP2W(Pay 2 Win? Well
recommended:
many of the reviews here are stating that it is a P2W game and I won't try to argue it because to an extent you can progress much faster with the cards in the game but it will only get you so far as to how much you are willing to spend on a free game and hornestly you really don't get much advantage over other. It is totally possible to get to the top without spending a single dime on this game. Just need a lot of hard work.
--- I would say this is 10% P2W and 90% hardwork.

Final Verdict: Yeah I would totally recommend trying to game out especailly if you are a big RTS-MMO fan and even if you are not its just fun to grow your village and take over other people and fight for glory. Just try to out
hoursPlayed: don't let these stupid one sentence "BAD!" "P2W" BS of a review get in your way of a great game.\n\nMy score of this game is 7.5 or 8 out of 10."

reviewText:
As compelling as the concept of this game is, it suffers the blight of freemium. Artificial wait times and paid perks are scattered across this game in excess.

Some will say that a company has a right and obligation to include ways to make money. They could have done that with a fifth of what they've injected into this game, and done fine besides.

Do yourself a favor. Spend the five or ten dollars up front to get a decent MMO, pay a monthly fee even. You still will pay less, for a far better experience.

reviewText:
I originally played this back in summer 2012 and returned summer 2014 to see what had improved. But like all free to play games it just has too many limitations and timers to recommend on a long term basis.

What's good - Watching your village becoming fully operational, scouting, trading, researching and seeing the occasional level up process, watching the battles from bandit camps, wolf lairs or your castle keep

What's bad - timeframe limits, the only thing that stops this is Maths but ultimately everything just takes too much time unless you play an insta-build card or time speed card and even then it only lasts a few hours. Castle building takes days, village building takes hours, raising your own military requires several researches and buildings which you must" have unless you like being attacked regularly by the AI and having no means of defending yourself thus losing resources. The card system is a mess and you have to click through them until you find what you wanted at the time. 7 day premium tokens and cards are where they want you to pay but really unless you can fully use a 7 or 30 day token dont even bother. If you want me paying £3 a throw I expect a 30 day token
recommended: I think the 7 day ones should be scrapped entirely. But back to my point
hoursPlayed: you need merchants+speed
voteText: scouts+speed
helpfulPercent: max housing capacity and military to fully get your moneys worth from the tokens
votesHelpful: all of which takes time. The biggest thing that kills the game however is research
votesTotal: once you run out of RP you either need to level up or spend gold to get more
votesFunny: Philosophy helps with this but like Maths it's a temporary fix at best.\n\nConclusion - when I first played I was around a few weeks and then left
commentsCount: there were several things I never got to experience like trading for gold or helping a house/faction take an area while watching big all out battles occur
column16: never raided a vilage
column17: never done parish heals
column18: and it goes on and on because the game is basically a giant timesink even with a premium token. Does the token speed everything up? No! Does the token provide you with extra research points? No! And guess what...when you use a token it ONLY applies to the world you were in instead of applying to ALL worlds
column19: sorry but I want my 7 or 30 days to cover all worlds that I play instead of just the 1
column20: forcing you to buy several tokens for the worlds you do play in assuming you can get any fun or enjoyment out of this game. Sorry Stronghold Kingdoms but ultimately you dont offer enough benefits to justify the time spent in the game and you don't do things you SHOULD be doing. Personally I dont have the time to stay up and wait for a timer to end just so I can see the end result. Which means I wont spend the money for cards and/or tokens unless I felt like I was getting proper value for money. You can do better and you can implement changes like what you did for banner creation or the recent avatar update. Give us players more options
column22: scrap the 7 day token and make the 30 day one viable for 3 pounds a throw
column23: give somebody like me enough of a reason to play and it's a very viable F2P game. But until you do these things I cannot recommend the game long term. This ends my review.\n\nFusionBunny"

reviewText:
Please do not support this game.  At first it seems like a cool game and fun.  But after you get into it you cannot really do anything worth while unless you have no life and can play 24/7 and if you are willing to spend hundreds of dollars if not thousands on buying cards.  The staff that support this game are crooks all the way up to the producers.  They will do things with your account and say too bad so sad we messed you up it is our fault but too bad you can suffer no matter how much they messed you up or how much money you spent or time on the game.

To even be in the top houses which seem to be all be run by the most arrogant ignorant gang like thugs.  People seem to support and follow these people yet a lot of these people are not even good at the game or are very nice people or even have any kind of good leadership qualities.  Yet people follow them and they run the show like a cult. And if you are not in it forget ever winning. After years of play you really end up with a bad experiance in the end.  Takes a year just to finish the first glory round even if you do make it and the map is dominated.  Maps usualy become totaly dominated by one group of people and thats it.  Do not expect fair play from players or the staff.

Do Not Buy this game and waste your time and money.  So many better games out there.

reviewText:
If you want to buy your victory play this. If you want rule because you earned it... Good luck. I find this a failed attempt, I play this game quite a bit, but that's only because Mobile is on the way. I feel if firefly gave this another try with natural geological formations instead of a flat boring same as everyone else's land, and if they didn't use these gimmicky cards, I believe this game would do way better, just slap a 15.00$ tag. Trust me, you'd make way more money off of sales in units compared to 3.00$ card sets... All in all, it sounds food on paper, executed poorly.

But, it is free, and the game actually does have a cool diplomacy system, and castle building is a waiting game but it's really pleasing watching your castle develop.

There is a wait time in building though, something used in cash cow money grubbing Clash of Clans mobile games, that's probably what killed this, it doesn't work because Firefly has a relatively small fanbase, being a AA" company as said by the head of the marketing department

reviewText:
If you want a decent enough game completely ruined by the pay to win factor then this is the game for you. The in game system for buying cards means that while it might not be a complete trade off for time put in the huge advantage of paying makes it a bad game to play. Cards can be used for army units, resources (including ones that help you level up and gain access to more technology and such), faster movement and more. Add on to that the fact if you get special tokens (using real money) you get building queues, tech queues and auto scouting / attacks.
Overall it isn't a bad game but the pay to win aspect does make it bad if you are not willing to invest loads for every advantage. Generally one of those games about long term however long term for me doesn't include having to constantly pay to be on par with other players.
Generally speaking knowledge and such will only go so far when everything is lacking compared to a heavily paying user.

EDIT:
Almost 2 years later tried to access game only to find out my account is locked out and I had to contact customer support. It seems customer support is investigating" issues with payments in the past so either they can't do anything in almost 2 years or they are just banning me for paying them and having issue with the service. AVOID LIKE  THE PLAGUE."

reviewText: I suppose I'll recommend this game if you aren't planning to play with friends/family/significant others using the same internet connection or don't mind paying real money to play with them. My boyfriend and I started playing two days ago with some friends. It was great! I needed some wood and he had a surplus so he traded me a few things. We're having fun, all is well. Today our free premium tokens expired. We are no longer permitted to trade with each other, send monks/troops to each other or anything else soley because we live together. I could deal with not being able to move my structures around and queue things - I can't deal with not being able to play with someone because I don't wish to spend money on this game.

reviewText: Played this game will over 1000 hours, and have a good amount of hours off steam as well. And one thing i have to say about this game is its extremely addictive. The start of the game can be a bit slow and boring but once you figure everything out and know what research is best for what you need and all around aspects of the game, its really fun. End game and joining a house is a big part of it and makes the game that much funner. Many people say its P2W, yet the cards do help extremely, it doesnt mean that someone without cards can't wreck too. There are treasure castles in order to get card points and card packs to keep up with all the cards. Theres also free cards weekly and quests in order to earn some extra rewards. Eventually, once you meet people and unify, the game becomes much more open and you dont have to pay a dime. I reccomend the steam starter pack, which will help you boost passed those beginning levels and get to dominating.

reviewText: A clock watching game.\nThat's pretty much what you'll spend all your time doing. It takes a lot of time and resources to do anything, and each time you do something it'll only cost more next time. Pretty obvious from the get-go that if you want anything interesting you have to pay. In all it's simply an endless grind. Farm stuff, build the castle, keep peasants happy and recruit them into soldiers, watch other dudes attack your castle, repair the castle, repeat for eternity. It's not a bad time waster, and it's too bad I haven't had a chance to really try the feudalism simulator they have going on; but I'd say your time and money is much better spent on the HD Stronghold and Crusader games.

reviewText:
This game was fun for what it was, but after waking up to log in and find that my castle had been ransacked and my only village taken over by a player of higher level it just left a nasty feeling in my gut.

Now if you were like me and lost your only village all is not lost you can setup a new village retain your rank and some other stats and are given some basic resources to start rebuilding and you are protected from attack for a couple of days so you can try again, but that doesn't seem that fun to me...

All those hours of collecting resources, building improvements, new buildings, conducting new research so I have access to said improvements and buildings. I can't say this game is worth the time if you lose almost everything you have been working towards.

If you like spending many hours working on something and then see it vanish by all means have at it. For now I am just going to shelve this one for now.

Also they need more variety in units what they got seems to be a bit minimalist to me but eh to each their own.

reviewText: Don’t do it, save your money and spend on something more enjoyable.  Firefly is the worst gaming company on the planet.  They refuse to enforce their own policy for account abuse, this game is overrun by players that use multiple accounts and as long and they are willing to spend money on premium tokens Firefly turns a blind eye.  Their servers are controlled by user groups that deploy alt accounts all over the map which makes it impossible to defend and control a territory unless you are willing to waste a lot of time and money as well.  This is not a good MMO because of the level of cheating allowed by Firefly because they see it as a revenue generator to allow cheating.  Find another game to spend your money on please; you will be much happier you did.  I can’t put it anymore simply, this is a terrible game, don’t waste your money on it and don’t allow yourself to get pulled in, the Firefly admins play favorites to those that spend the most money and are willing to ban players that have any skills that threaten the status quo.  Seriously stay away from this game…..

reviewText:
I've been playing that game for a little moe than 3 years now so I'm a veteran. I've been playing on 4 different servers since the beginning and I'm telling you honestly don't ever play this game.

First of all it's dangerously addictive but on top of that it's just a bad game runned by people who have no interest at all in the health of their community. They are only motivated in creating more and more opportunity to fill their pocket by tempting players with agressive promotions.

Even if it requires to create new servers with different gameplay and close others that they find no worthy enough to keep alive knowing that people haver invested themselves a lot and still play on it. We've come to a point where they have lost control of the essential basis of that game which is teamwork.

By throwing at their members continuously new ways to start all over on a better server the team spirit is slowly fading out while people who have gone so far together just quit completely bored by way Firefly Studio threat their members. I'm one of them and I wish that this company can assume a bad comment about their game and that they wont delete it the second I post it.

Others leave the game only because the game at all mostly bases on PvP as become more annoying than fun. This game is not free to play, it's a pay to win and cleary those who have the deepest pocket will keep winning over and over again. That's the way it is so don't waste your time installing that game or any other Firefly game.

Their are tons ofgames better than this one where you can waste your time :)
