reviewText: The game as a whole can be fun but the gameplay itself is often very tedious and boring.  The best aspects of the game are the politcs: joining a guild, interacting with your allies and using your combined numbers to accomplish something.  Whether it be getting a certain person elected head of a county or conquering all the villages belonging to a certain House in a region its the politics where the game is interesting.\n\nBut the actual game mechanics themselves are boring; often extremely boring.  Most of the time I spent playing I was actually surfing the internet and only occasionally checking in on what was happening.  Things can move very slowly.  Wars can be frustrating as well since the game lets you spend money to protect your castles from attack.  You'll often find yourself logging on after work or school to find half your villages have been conquered and they are immune to attack for several days so you have no way of getting them back.  And these are villages you've spent months building up only to have it all thrown away when you weren't even playing.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:

All of this sounds really cool, until I realised to achieve this I had spent about £200. You will spend hours a day keeping your alliances in place and then as soon as you go away for a day find your villages missing. Oh you've been destroyed.

On the plus side you are now free from the chains of P2W. Uninstall this videogame crack whilst you still can.

reviewText:
Remember that anything I say is my opinion and mine alone--

Alright, here is a simple review I have to type for you to see to easilly decide if you want the game.

Pros :
Tutorial
Amazing Soundtrack
Addicting Gameplay
'Notice board' is up to date with raids and attacks gone wrong or gold.

Cons :
Not like original Stronghold games, whereas this is multiplayer and not singleplayer. (1/2 due to this being amazing as an online game.)
In order to win you have to spend real-life money on a virtual online game to dominate anyone.

Now, what I have experienced in this game.

*First Time Playing*
Is introduced by lilerk, a friend of mine.
Continues to grow and create my kingdom, only to be stuck in the village level and un-able to fend off invasions due to no help from other kingdoms.

*Second Time Playing*
Restarted, lilerk gives me mercs so I can fend off my kingdom.
Stays in village level.

*Third Time Playing*
Is halfway through the ranks but still can't fend off kingdom due to no mercs ALIVE.
Is invaded each hour and loses control on populus

*Fourth Time Playing*
Writes review to show my pros and cons and experience.


DO I RECOMMEND THIS GAME?

If you are a Stronghold fan and knows what it takes to become a bad-butt king, yes, I recommend it.
If you are new to the series and this is your first time playing an online kingdom game where the tutorial is short, no, why? Because it's simply PAY TO WIN.

Remember that anything I say is my opinion and mine alone--

reviewText:
This game isn’t for everyone although I would recommend it with a few caveats.. You only have to look at the number of hours I have played this game to see I enjoy it (I have probably played just as many hours in the stand alone client as on steam!)

However it is also evidence of the downside to this game, it has a tendency to take a hold of players that get very involved in the game. It can be hard to leave the game alone and you will find yourself thinking about the game when you perhaps should be focused on something more productive. This is only exacerbated by the persistent nature of the game and, for the most part, the awesome community that support this game.

There is also a pay to win aspect to this game, as you might have noticed by the other reviews.  Some benefits are only available to those who invest not only time but money into the game., But you have to remember the game has to be supported and without money the developers can’t do this. Hiding features behind a paywall though is never popular and it is something I can not defend. Automated trading and having a requirement to put money into the game in order to unlock more than a measly number of free in game stratagy cards are two of such features I would point out.

However as long as you know this going into the game you shouldn’t be disappointed. It may take you longer to achieve your goals in Stronghold Kingdoms if you play it entirely Free To Play, you may also have a hard time going up against people who play it Pay To Win (and know what they’re doing) but there’s no reason why you still can’t have a lot of fun playing this game and meat a lot of cool and interesting people along the way.

reviewText:
Well, I'm a new player... Needless to say im getting butt ♥♥♥♥♥ by my stronger neighbors around me.

Starting the game:

It gives you a 2 day taste of the full premium experience... but only for 2 days... In these 2 days you can advance rather rapidly, building 7 buildings 1 after the other, and in general just feeling like the game is not broken. You also get a 2 day slot of no one can attack me" which is great
date:
I mean people would always then attack the newbie for easy resources. You research you expand very rapidly and then your protection is gone!

Mid Game:

This is when the game starts to fail... there is no limit for those players that are substantially stronger to just go and wipe out smaller players. This game is not new player friendly! Immediatly after ym protection is gone I get raided by my super powerful neighbor
recommended: he first sends 20 peasants. Nothing too bad right! Then he just swarmes me 3 times untill I fall and eviscerates what was once my wooden fortress. New players have no way to defend themselves once their premium trial is over and their "spawn Protection" is over.\n\nFeatures: I love the research system
hoursPlayed: makes you think ahead. As well as teh fortress system.\n\nI hate the preimium Pay2Win ability. The fact that higher ranking players can just swarm your village every 2 days to plunder you for your resources. They also don't need to micro as much as the newbies since they have 7 buildings building which takes up to 4 hours whereas the newbie has 1 and that takes 20 min tops. The game is jsut not newbie friendly

reviewText:
Could have been good for a free game, but it will wear at your patience faster than mine!

It's finally got me - I cannot play this anymore, ain't nobody got time for that! Shame as this could have been a really good game. I have a lot of patience, even for really REALLY slow games like this one, but this has finally got me. You may find it entertaining and fun at first as I did, and the map is very good, but as it rapidly slows down, it becomes increasingly frustrating, and even multiple villages/worlds cannot keep you busy and entertained.
If you want to feel pressured into spending money on a 'free' game to succeed, or want to end up staring blankly at your villagers making repetitive movements while you wait an hour to build each building, send out a scout or start each research, and have every intention of playing this daily (as your village gets wiped after a few days of non-play, and you will in the most part have to start over), then sure, I guess this is the game for you. If you can log on.

I really wanted to love this game, I gave it a very good run.... but I've had enough, and I dont feel like waiting around on it this week :(

reviewText: Do not play this game. It is a pay to win game.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Though the game itself is fun to play at first. It heavilly follows the pay to win model of gaming that doesn't work with the majority of people, who don't have money to spare. I went into the game expecting the average free to play game, of no initial cost, with a cash shop. They do have this, but the encourage you to spend money you may not have in order to do a ton of things.
One of the major beefs I have, is it's Premium Service. They encourage you, everytime you log off, that if you don't have it to get it. And that makes sense to do something like that. But the concept of 'Commanding even when you are off' Breaks the balance of the game.
Here is why:
Say you have two players near each other in-game. One of them, who we will name James, has a weekly job and a family. He plays a few  games online during the weekend and days off. He also can't afford to buy Crowns. Now, we also have another player, we will name him Jack. Jack lives with his parents and goes to highschool. His father has a good job, and so pays Jack a large allowence that he can spend on anything. He spends it on Crowns every time. Say he also gets the Premium Service and sets everything to max.
James, the man with a job, will have the things Jack, the teenager, at a much slower rate due to money spent on the game.
And so, I declare Stronghold Kingdoms, as a Pay to Win game. Not a Free to Play game. For anyone interested, avoid.

reviewText: I've never seen microtransactions effect a game so much. Listen, people will literally spend HUNDREDS of dollars on this game. I'm not even kidding. I joined The Sneaky Faction in House 9. It's full of greedy and evil prepubescent kids who beg their parents for over $100 to make yourself OP as ♥♥♥♥. Seriously, this game moves EXTREMELY slow. But the progress in a year can be crushed into a week with money. Holy Hell, I was just about to get a fourth village, and because I was AFK, I was stabbed in the back. I had three villages, two of them HIGHLY developed, and one very new. They took over my two strongholds and left me with my little village, which I called Meth Lab. Here's some advice-Choose an area with no population and don't get involved with any factions or houses. Or don't get this at all.\n\nJust now, I've told my friends" at Sneaky that they're cheats and I've made my Coat Of Arms a hand sticking the finger. How about this-get a REAL Stronghold game

reviewText: What a load of crap!\nAfter ignoring the negative reviews, I sunk a month into this game, on daily to build up my name. Just as things were getting better and I could stand on my feet, a max level player attacked and took all three of my villages while I was offline. With no real defence I was forced to start from the bottom once more. There is no way to stop this and I would urge anyone think about installing this not to do so, the pay-to-win experince can be overcome but not total destruction.

reviewText:
Amazing game you have to stick to it tho. There are so many great things about this game its too hard to single a few out but let me try.

1. The Leveling up system in this game is so rewarding! watching your village grow your titles change makes all the time worth it

2. The other people in this game are so helpful and kind if you ever find yourself stuck all you need to do is message one and odds are they will do their best to help in anyway

3. although it takes time to get past the slight learning curve this game is extremely rewarding! from collecting resources to managing scouting missions to building a castle like no other it has great return value making you keep coming back just for one more hour.

Over all i would reccomend this game to both new and veteran people to this genre of game
voteText: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Brilliant MMO, I love the castle building and warfare and the way it has the characters from the other Stronghold games such as the Rat, Wolf, Pig and Snake. The researching and honour system is genius but I believe it could improve by adding a farming mode/Capture only world like in the original Stronghold games were the was a construction mode where you could build in peace I would love for that to be added also.
The new Wolf AI world was very fun to play as there was a feeling of unity from the community that is rare in most games these days as everyone worked together to defeat the AI and take control of their world.

Over-all it's a brilliant game and I reccomend it to everyone however I'd like my idea of the farm world/Construction World to be considered.

Cheers,

iAura

reviewText:
This game is a brilliant mass of brutal abuse.

You play the game, build up through sheer effort.

And them BAM! Some Foreign guy who cannot even speak any known language to man attacks you, any friends you make, any powerful allies you make, any one you have even interacted with and then sets off a war.

BOOM, everything has gone to ♥♥♥♥ and only one power remains on the entire map. They absorb or destroy everyone and then the developers release a brand new map set in a new or expanded region and the game continues.

666/420 would play again.

PS. Don't forget the rich foriegners who have so much money they just buy their way through everything.

reviewText: A nice little game, people do complain about pay to win, but that really doesn't exist. The only time you will get randomly attacked is either by a bandit, and the other people around you will help take them down, and usually they never attack you before they are taken out. 2nd reason is you are in war with them, and that makes perfect sense. So why does it matter if other people are buying everything, if it does not affect you? Be glad you have patience, to wait for everything and a wallet. Game can take quite a while to get into/back into but once you get your army up and get into wars it can be quite fun. Also, 99% of people I have met in the game are pretty nice.

reviewText: Stronghold kingdoms is a difficult game to explain at the outset, so I'll just go over the basics without going past a few paragraphs. It's a good game, though it requires a lot of patience, for reasons you can read below if you want. In sum, it's for a patient, deliberate type of gamer, and is certainly a rewarding experience. Onto the real meat:\n\nYou'll see pretty much every negative review on this game say it's pay to win"

reviewText: Played this game only for six months, did sink a few quid on it, but I really didn't need to. We got the parishes under our control without even really being noticed by this guy.\nIt was only after we tried to muscle in on a third parish; I received a message from him only saying bye". I then noticed 3 icons moving towards my villages
date: and four over to my friends. He destroyed everything. We tried to send our troops to attack his villages in a pathetic attempt attempt to save ourselves. Or at least take a bit of him with us. Our troops were slaughtered in a tower grid of a village. His troops marched right through our 1 stone block walls and that was that really. We both stopped playing after that. reviewText:
highly adictive, i have twice as many hours on the server that are not registered on steam.
if you have a lot of of free time and want a drug to take out of the real world this is the game for you.

I kicked the habit like two years ago, just went back now to check out the new worlds but i´ll not get sucked into that again.

some people say it´s pay to win, i dunno, by the time i was playing i got a lot of free crowns and cards from amazon, they had a reward for registering at the time. and i only made 2 minimum purchases to activate the quest meter to receive cards at maximum speed. But i havent even spent the crowns i bought, just a few(i still have 1k crowns sitting around), not even all of the ones i got for free from amazon, and I was one of the strongest players in world 4 two years ago.

So I dont think it´s pay to win, you need premium tokens ofc, but not all the time and you get many from quests and if amazon is still giving crowns you can get like a year of premium with those, unless you want to be the king, I assume then you would need to spend some cash, but I managed to run 8 parishes at once and became the governor of the province, started a faction, which i named 'The Night's whatch', and it got really strong, the house i belonged ruled over 2 of the 4 countries, I had like 50 vassals, all of that without spending crowns or barely spending. it´s a lot to handle.

Obs. i noticed now people have way more villages than it was possible when i played, so the numbers above may seem insignificant, but 2 years ago you could hardly get any more powerful than that.

In short, great game, but be careful, cocaine may seem great at first too

reviewText:
Stronghold Kingdoms
What should i say about this? Its a GREAT MMO.
I could write a Book about it. Its just awesome with all the possibilitys, the most awesome feature is: The Players decide the Game. You can join a house/faction. And these factions are allied or at war with other factions its possible for you and your clan/faction to just conquer the world!
You can even become a spy, join the enemy faction, work your way up (pretend to had a fight with your own faction) and destroy the enemy from the inner.

The possibility are endless since the world is player driven!

AND ANY BODY WHO TALKS ABOUT PAY 2 WIN: JUST STFU, IDIOTS! it is definitly NOT P2W!
It doesnt really matter if you pay or not. Its just the usual: make things easier with real money. And whats the problem. the devs/publisher need to earn money. You think they are making games for free, idiots?!
What you get for Money is a premium account so you can qeue buildings and research. good when you go to work or something.

And you can buy card packs with RANDOM Cards. like your scouts reach the location sooner 2000 wood, and so on. Thats not gamebreaking, just a kickstart for newer settlements (you can have up to 20+).
You even get cards without money, and the REAL good cards like, instant building or instant research (1 time use only!) are REALLY rare. since you open card packs like in yugioh or fifa ultimate team, you dont know what you get. most time you get cards that help you a little. so stfu idiots!

reviewText:
This game starts to slowly suck you in.
In the end you end up spending vast ammounts of time and money to recieve the extras needed to be successful.
I'm sure many people resist the temptation much like myself however you soon realise that your level of success depends almost entirely on how much you are prepared to spend.
Unfortunately for you; someone always seems prepared to spend more................it is a bottomless pit!

Good game - great Idea - be prepared to spend a small fortune.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Stronghold Kingdoms is in my opinion the best city building stragey game i have ever played online and i have tried quite a few. this game is very unique in that you have AIs to attack and also they attack you such as all 4 of the AI castles from the stronghold line of games such as the rat which is the easiest to deal with up to the wolf which is hardest. Thier are also wolf lairs, bandit camps which you attack for quests or just honor. the game is based on an honor system u advace by gaining honor. THe game icorperates a research system you can do very little without researching to do it first from building diferent buildings to troop types and even religion. There is an extensive religious system where you use monks to do things like heal deseases and protect ur villages and things of that nature. The maps r devided into parishes, counties, statesand countries. these parishes require a person (called a steward) this person takes charge and builds builds in the parish that help the others who live in the parish this can range from use troops there to take out the AIs to building guilds which when upgraded give benifits to all citizens within that parish. You can join with other players in your area to form factions and house these factions and house go through what is known as a glory race in which they r trying to be the only one left at the end of the race winning house of this race at the end of an age get fabulous in game prizes. There are four ages each with it's own unique set of rules. There are also cards that allow u to do things in the game like make your troops faster, make free troops,  help production of goods, all kinds of diferent things. As I hope u can see from just vthis breif discription of the game that it has alot to offer you many hours of great enjoyable play time. I would very highly recomened this game to all stratagy city building game lovers even if you have never played a game like this I would encourage anyone who likes online gaming to give it  a try.\n\nSpitfireSam

Ok

reviewText:
I'm not proud of the fact that I ended up giving up over two thousand hours of my life to this piece of crap. It was terrible ♥♥♥♥ing addiction that I'm glad I got over. I got the starter pack free with Stronghold HD and this rubbish has been stuck in my library ever since.

The fact that they recycled a lot of the assets(graphics, music, sounds, etc.) in this game from the first Stronghold means I can never enjoy that amazing game again without being reminded of this.

The gameplay is the typical strategy" pay 2 win
date: wait-fest ♥♥♥♥ you'd expect from a browser F2P. The combat is composed of you throwing hundreds of units against your enemy's walls
recommended: with the only real control you have over your units being over their spawn location. And then you have to wait for them to casually stroll across the landscape/Irish Sea(the latter of takes literal days without paying for speed boosts) before the attack you planned finally comes to fruition. Even then
hoursPlayed: you have to send multiple simultaneous attacks in order to actually capture or completely destroy a village
voteText:
because they can repair all the damage you dealt and protect their village from being attacked in the time it takes for you to send your next attack.

Later on the wait times for villages can take entire weeks if you don't pay. Literal real time weeks. And castles(the defense portion of your village) will take an entire month to be fully built. I can not stress this enough: the one line of defence preventing other players from freely raiding and burning down your village whenever they feel like it takes an entire month to be built. And this is a game where you can lose all of that in the blink of an eye due to multiple attacks hitting your castle within the span of a few seconds.

This is a game that requires you to be awake and playing the game for as much time as you possibly can. If you aren't online 24/7
helpfulPercent: then you are at serious risk of losing villages to attacks during the night.\n\nThe "community" in this game is the worst. I'd imagine the only reason it hasn't accumulated as much infamy as most MOBAs or other notably toxic games is because it isn't nearly as popular as those games (thank god). The game technically has 'rules
votesHelpful: ' but everyone ignores them because the mods rarely do anything about the cheaters. People in my old faction(don't know or care what those are actually called) even bragged about having dozens of alt accounts! You know a game is screwed up when people are bragging about cheating.\n\nEven the mods are cheating! Some of them even abuse their mod status on top of the cheating. I've seen screenshots of conversations between mods and other players where the mods try and bait the other players into insulting them or raging
votesTotal: just so they have an excuse for a ban.\n\nThe meta-game revolves around helping your house take huge tracts of land and keeping hold of them for a long-♥♥♥ time. Your house earns points for this and the first house to recieve the goal number of points wins a prize. And after months of work
votesFunny: if your house wins
commentsCount: each member gets a bunch of comparatively meager prizes. The winning house also gets a post in the news section on the the world select screen declaring their victory which will get buried shortly afterwards by other houses' victories on other worlds.\n\nI am not sure why I found that ♥♥♥♥ even remotely fun."

reviewText:
Alright, many people tend to become expert after a 'mere' 300 ours of gaming. I am approaching the 5,000 hours, so I have been around. And this is a game to pay to win, some people say? Not true. It's possible to buy cards that give advantages. But spending many hours online does get you free cards as well as a bonus. And when fighting a player, using cards does not give an overwhelming advantage. Attacking skills do, and building strong castles helps too.

Lastly, some commentator says starting players are being attacked for they are very weak. Yes, starting players are weak, but for an experienced player to attack a starting player, there is a severe penalty for the experienced player. So starting players are not going to be attacked by the stronger players.

So does paying help? A bit. But it can be countered by staying online a lot like I do. In fact to be online a lot has a greater effect than to pay your way. Paying players will receive some small advantages, but not enough to change the odds when they are stacked against them. Please, if you want to give your opinion, stay with the game long enough to give a good advice.

reviewText: People have been complaining about pay to win stuff here, but honestly, if you build your villages up you can start attacking treasure castles multiple times a day, and that earns you random levels on the treasure wheel, which rewards gold, card packs, and card points, you should be able to amass quite a few cards just spending a month or two on 100-400 day old server.  Then you can save all those cards, really, save them, never use em, and then wait for a new world to start, and you can blow all your cards in the first week and get the biggest jump possible, and then it wont matter how many cards people use later, you will have had an advantage from day 1, turn 1.

So starting players are not going to be attacked by the stronger players.

So does paying help? A bit. But it can be countered by staying online a lot like I do. In fact to be online a lot has a greater effect than to pay your way. Paying players will receive some small advantages, but not enough to change the odds when they are stacked against them. Please, if you want to give your opinion, stay with the game long enough to give a good advice.

reviewText:
I'm not proud of the fact that I ended up giving up over two thousand hours of my life to this piece of crap. It was terrible ♥♥♥♥ing addiction that I'm glad I got over. I got the starter pack free with Stronghold HD and this rubbish has been stuck in my library ever since.

The fact that they recycled a lot of the assets(graphics, music, sounds, etc.) in this game from the first Stronghold means I can never enjoy that amazing game again without being reminded of this.

The gameplay is the typical strategy" pay 2 win
date: wait-fest ♥♥♥♥ you'd expect from a browser F2P. The combat is composed of you throwing hundreds of units against your enemy's walls
recommended: with the only real control you have over your units being over their spawn location. And then you have to wait for them to casually stroll across the landscape/Irish Sea(the latter of takes literal days without paying for speed boosts) before the attack you planned finally comes to fruition. Even then
hoursPlayed: you have to send multiple simultaneous attacks in order to actually capture or completely destroy a village
voteText:
because they can repair all the damage you dealt and protect their village from being attacked in the time it takes for you to send your next attack.

Later on the wait times for villages can take entire weeks if you don't pay. Literal real time weeks. And castles(the defense portion of your village) will take an entire month to be fully built. I can not stress this enough: the one line of defence preventing other players from freely raiding and burning down your village whenever they feel like it takes an entire month to be built. And this is a game where you can lose all of that in the blink of an eye due to multiple attacks hitting your castle within the span of a few seconds.

This is a game that requires you to be awake and playing the game for as much time as you possibly can. If you aren't online 24/7
helpfulPercent: then you are at serious risk of losing villages to attacks during the night.\n\nThe "community" in this game is the worst. I'd imagine the only reason it hasn't accumulated as much infamy as most MOBAs or other notably toxic games is because it isn't nearly as popular as those games (thank god). The game technically has 'rules
votesHelpful: ' but everyone ignores them because the mods rarely do anything about the cheaters. People in my old faction(don't know or care what those are actually called) even bragged about having dozens of alt accounts! You know a game is screwed up when people are bragging about cheating.\n\nEven the mods are cheating! Some of them even abuse their mod status on top of the cheating. I've seen screenshots of conversations between mods and other players where the mods try and bait the other players into insulting them or raging
votesTotal: just so they have an excuse for a ban.\n\nThe meta-game revolves around helping your house take huge tracts of land and keeping hold of them for a long-♥♥♥ time. Your house earns points for this and the first house to recieve the goal number of points wins a prize. And after months of work
votesFunny: if your house wins
commentsCount: each member gets a bunch of comparatively meager prizes. The winning house also gets a post in the news section on the the world select screen declaring their victory which will get buried shortly afterwards by other houses' victories on other worlds.\n\nI am not sure why I found that ♥♥♥♥ even remotely fun."

reviewText:
This game can be fun but has many faults.
1. Premium features make no sense.
I should not have to buy premium for a month just to get standered features. Want a building and research que? To bad you've got to pay for it. These times also continue to increase as the game goes on but its really inconvienent for most to log in every 17 mins, then 30 just to que something.

2. The developers don't know what they're doing or are just lazy.
I've seen smaller teams do more work in less time than this entire game existed. Most of the resources go into making new worlds and not improving the ones we're already playing in. This basically means little new features for the game and just more rpetty maps. It's as if they're scared or something.
I don't think they know this, but if you actually update the game play to not be the same since release it might be benificial. Actually improving on graphics and other aspects of the game. Heck, maybe even a new research branch one day but nope. Apparently we will just sit here with no actual updates to the game.

3. New maps/worlds are fun but yet kill the game
Basically a new type of map gets released most people go play it. When 3 months pass (I beleive) a new world gets released ussually of the same map. This ussually causes a severe population drop in the new world compared to the other. Example would be the Global conflict world 1 and 2. 2 had like what 20+k at launch and still does. Number 2 has around 5k and a few of them are actually playing.
Improve on the worlds and make us actually want to stay through the ages, don't keep releasing new world. It be more beneficial if you have a few worlds but encourages newer players. That way the world stays alive and gets a constant flow of new players.
More points to those who do not play the game will unsderstand

4. Horrible administration and moderation
Mods don't have the power to ban people from the game, they barely have the power to mure players. Heck they don't even have a proper report system to report cheaters. There are many cheaters in these worlds. A great example would be Global conquest 2 world. The lands of Republic of congo" are filled with alt accounts. These accounts give players an advantage over others. Since day 1 there had been OVER 20 ALT ACCOUNTS. They're literally named village and player 6003
recommended: 6005 and so on. Heck it's even reported on the main forums and they still exist. All are the lowest rank so they probably were used to keep others out and to spawn parishes.\n"Hmm I wonder who did it
hoursPlayed: couldn't possibly be the only 2 players there that are higher than a village idiot
voteText:
nooo."

5. Lazy updates
Read above reasons

That being said its not the worse game ever
It provides political struggle and competition

About stronghold kingdoms
Stronghold Kingdoms (SHK) is a massively multi-player online real time strategy game (MMORTS) with a Medieval castle building theme. It was developed by Firefly Studios and based upon their commercially successful and popular Stronghold series of games. Firefly Studios started development of Stronghold Kingdoms in 2007 as their first entry into the MMO[1] genre. The first Alpha test began in 2009 and was open only to 150 players.[2] These were drawn from previous testers of Firefly Studios games, and volunteers of other prominent fansites. Afterwards, an open Beta was run for just under 2 years before the games official release on the 17th of October 2012.

In addition to the central theme of castle construction and design, Stronghold Kingdoms incorporates a variety of architectural, economic, military, agricultural, mercantile, industrial and political elements which challenge players ability to prioritize, direct work-flow and resources and administrate their holdings in the manner of a medieval land holder or noble. An individual player's success is not entirely predicated upon the ability to defeat computer-generated enemies, but also upon teamwork with fellow players.

The player begins relatively alone, one village amongst others in a single parish. From this beginning, strategic decisions are made and dialogue established with fellow parish members which introduces the social aspect of Stronghold Kingdoms. All players can vie for stewardship of the parish, dependent on rank. When two or more players wish to be Steward they can negotiate to decide who will take control of the parish, or take it by force, razing out the opposing players village from that parish. If Theology is researched, then monks can be deployed to infiltrate the parish and influence the vote. This is usually referred to as a monk war in the game vernacular. When the successful candidate becomes steward they gain control of the parish army along with the ability to set taxes (tithe), and build the necessary guilds to improve life for all in the parish.

It was developed by Firefly Studios and based upon their commercially successful and popular Stronghold series of games. Firefly Studios started development of Stronghold Kingdoms in 2007 as their first entry into the MMO[1] genre. The first Alpha test began in 2009 and was open only to 150 players.[2] These were drawn from previous testers of Firefly Studios games, and volunteers of other prominent fansites. Afterwards, an open Beta was run for just under 2 years before the games official release on the 17th of October 2012.

In addition to the central theme of castle construction and design, Stronghold Kingdoms incorporates a variety of architectural, economic, military, agricultural, mercantile, industrial and political elements which challenge players ability to prioritize, direct work-flow and resources and administrate their holdings in the manner of a medieval land holder or noble. An individual player's success is not entirely predicated upon the ability to defeat computer-generated enemies, but also upon teamwork with fellow players.

The player begins relatively alone, one village amongst others in a single parish. From this beginning, strategic decisions are made and dialogue established with fellow parish members which introduces the social aspect of Stronghold Kingdoms. All players can vie for stewardship of the parish, dependent on rank. When two or more players wish to be Steward they can negotiate to decide who will take control of the parish, or take it by force, razing out the opposing players village from that parish. If Theology is researched, then monks can be deployed to infiltrate the parish and influence the vote. This is usually referred to as a monk war in the game vernacular. When the successful candidate becomes steward they gain control of the parish army along with the ability to set taxes (tithe), and build the necessary guilds to improve life for all in the parish.

reviewText:
NOTE: I had fun while I played, otherwise wouldn't play at all. Having in-game connections helped. I still recommend it for the sake of trying and knowing what is what, it's not for everyone. I didn't feel that I needed to Pay4Win to get a good game and be a good player. Sure, you won't get to the feet of those that love to spend their pennies, but not bad either.

Aaaah...I remember playing this game not so long ago. Once I logged in I had the gut feeling that I was going in for a treat at first glance on the map. It looked peaceful at first but the objective in this was quite clear:

Teamwork
War
Dominate
Rule

The first thing I did was set me up good with the parish ruler and all the parish player. Help each other out, ask what were the objectives of that specific parish and keep in touch so to work together on setting up a good strong parish. In no time I'm recommended a faction since I had a good set of objectives and knew how to team around and keep in touch. A sense of loyality eventually grows, got to trust those more experienced and keep in touch with everyone (again) to dominate and secure all the parishes/counties belonging to your faction.
Once secured we just got to keep the rule, enter a wee bit of peace time and in a flash trouble brews and once again, lose some win some (territories).

Sounds quite exciting doesn't it? Seems like your thing? It was for me, too.

The game's diplomacy is brutal and if you end up in a very active territory you should be ready to be farmed/conquered and do the same too. Unless you've got more military driven people to back you up, climbing the ranks as a peace keeper will be very very painful and very well a waste of time. You basically have to set up two main initial roles at least: Fighter or Support.

I was a fighter and got to admit it was one of the best online fun (browse(kinda)) experiences I had. The communication, the fighting, the commerce, the conquering the thrill of getting payback and crushing opponents knowing I was making them angry in real life.

But after 1 month and a half I had enough. This game requires a certain commitment and while I knew how to manage the time, this game isn't for the person that doesn't know how to manage time of online fun. Otherwise you'll look at the clock and your wife/husband/partner/errand fell asleep or was ditched waiting for you. Unless one does know how to manage time, this game will only suit retired people or very very bored people with much time to spare.

I recommend the game because of its strategical competitivity and how it can all turn into a messy chaos with all backstabbing and having to rely on teamwork/diplomacy for survival. The collective ladder climb. If you're a competitive person that seeks some competition in the online gaming department this game is a great provider of such.

Just be aware of the timing downside and be very manageable. Otherwise stay away.

Cheers

reviewText: This game is awesome for the casual player. If you like building and cooperating with players for common victory then you will enjoy this. I prefer this much more to other similar games played such as Evony. The devs have thought out the game a lot better with regards to its features and longevity of playing. So far it is the kind of game I will always jump on everyday and build my armies and villages until war breaks out then it will be a fight for control!\nIf you want high action and fast pace then try the 3D action version of this game. If you prefer to play over longer periods more casually and want to build up forces and factions with other people then go for this. The premium features are quite good too and not to pricey to buy a premium token for a month.\nAll I can say is jump on and join a world and try it for yourself.

reviewText:
Strategic game
Great for any age
Fun for hours on end alone or with friends (it takes a little while to get yourself settled in the beginning)
Playing against other steam players
Free and any in game purchases are not over the top so they do not have such an extreme advantages
Side Note free players can earn items that you can buy with in game quests and treasure castles.
This is just my rant of the game
This is a game of patience, like a great game of chess. This strategic game is built on hard work, the longer you play the stronger you become as a player. You will make many friends and enemies. You can chose different types of players, for intense a monk, farmer or a warrior and if you so choose all three. This all depends on what you chose to research. Over time you will be able to upgrade your player and become the king of the world if you chose or a humble player. This game is intents to the point of having wars with groups of players band together under one flag to dominate the world and in the world USA is at a world war with hundreds of online players fighting for world domination.

So do not be afriad to hit me up if you want a friend to play or need help

reviewText: I've been playing this game for over a year now and it is by far one of the best MMO War Games that I have played. With the monthly updates and near 100% uptime you never have to worry about this game crashing or bugging out. I love the card system and the ability to increase pretty much every aspect of the game with cards. From increasing the speed of your scouts and troops to the ammount of food you make in a day everything can be made better. Also One of the biggest selling points about this game that got me into it was the customizable Castles that you create 100% yourself. Other games dont allow you to do this which is what makes me like this game even more. Also seeing the scouts/merchants/armies/monks going across the map is pretty awesome. Being able to see just who is getting attacked and by how many armies is just awesome. Nothing better than seeing 10+ armies flying across the map to 1 village. Honestly, what got me to play this game in the first place was the fact that they had a USA map and that I could have a village in the actual state/county that I live in. No other game has their map based on Real Life locations that I am aware of which makes Stronghold Kingdom that much better. I strongly recommend this game for anyone who likes realtime war games. Username - XxMalachixX

reviewText:
First of all , im a Strategy game nut. Stronghold kingdoms is a good and fun game where there is alot I like about it and some things I do no like. I love the complex of what you can do and be in this game and the different strategys you can use to defeat your opponents such as taking his castles by force or beating your opponents in monking ( political power by votes etc) and even taking his weapons / food and resources. The one downfall I do not like about the game is how much cards can help you or aid you in winning over your opponent who has not buy cards. Than again this game is free so they gotta make there money somehow.

As a little review of the game you basically start off with 1 village and begin making buildings and upgrading your castles to defend either against AI's or real players from either destroying your castle, pillaging , ransaking ( destroying your buildings you built inside the village ) or even destroying the castle all togethor.

Also in the game there are what is called Parishs, and each village inside this parish gets to votes once per day electing one person to contol the parish as a steward of it. There is also even more seats that you can earn thru people voting for you to be the leader.

You level so to the speak from Honour, Honour is used to lvl up thru the ranks earning your more villages , research points and the ability to attack your opponents. You can earn this thru buildings , Banqueting, defending your castle from troops or from attacking AI.

There is so much more and I can go on and on but Overall its a fun and great game as i have over 700+ hrs played and strongly recommend it.

reviewText: Not that I installed steam, because I wanted to get the prizes from the giveaway, I always wanted to share my opinion on this game. reviewText:
1153 Hours played on 7 different worlds and that's just on the Steam client.

Do I reccomend this game?

Well if you want to forget about sleeping properly, going out on the lash or spending a day at work without a laptop for lunch time use then I do heartilly reccomend this game.

Cards (Pay real cash for) are a big part of the game as are 'Premium Tokens' ti gain a build queue, research queue and a few snacky features.

It's not a game for 'going it Alone'. Join a faction, your faction joins a house and your leadership (or you after a while if you want to get there) can decide who to befriend and who to attack.

With over 1500 hours invested on and off over the past couple of years it's IMHO a great way of thinking you will log in for a quick 20m to have a checkup at 7 in the evening and then think oh **** its 1am and im up in 5 hours for work

reviewText: This game is absolutely stunning for strategy and intelligent quick thinking. Large scale wars, faction vs faction, House vs House. The thousands, the millions of players choosing to either share and get along in a lasting community, or to destroy anyone in their path. The game has it's ups and downs. Up: You can have 40 villages as of current! There are tons of ranks to work towards, and many many unlockables and boosts you can get for no charge, including researches (You may buy spare points with in-game gold), you can own tons of landmarks such as Counties, Parishes, Provinces, and even the Countries themselves! Downs: You're prone to destruction at a low level if you don't find yourself protected by a high standing Liege Lord. My Liege Lord is my grandfather, who currently holds a high position, in the top 500 players globally, with over 14 villages, he's a Crown Prince. I chose a small island community, which may have it's ups as far as being seclusive and peaceful goes, but the resources can be a bit slim until you are able to go over-seas.\n\nWill I reccomend the game? To be quite frank, ♥♥♥♥ YEAH I WILL!!! Nothing can really amount to this game's content and abilities, without completely copying it's style.

reviewText:
very addicting, its free so what have you to lose other than countless hours of you life on here?
pros- they have a max army per village you have, the reason thats a good thing is that it doesnt matter when you start, if you are fast and tactical you can fight anyone
very helpful community
if you dont like asking people for help, simply hit the questionmark that you can find on literally every screen and it takes you to the wiki of the game so theres no worries about not knowing what a certain building does or how to unlock buildings and units
they have cards that give you a little extra bonus but cost money to get the packs, however you can get up to a max of 2 of these cards for free a day, if you dont like what you got simply save up 5 of them and swap them for points and after awhile you can buy your card of choice without spending a penny

cons-pay to win, ive seen one person single handedly take out an entire house (alliance) single handedly because they spent alot of money on the game, to get around that you have to keep your head low and not aggrivate people unless you dont mind losing your villas or have alot of cash to blow off to keep up with them... but, as i said earlier, the community is pretty chill, ive yet to get attacked for no reason, only during war time so you only have to worry about heavy spenders if you ware going to war with them

all in all a great game to pass the time, takes time to build stuff so you can minimize the window and do something else as you wait out the build time, completely recommend it

reviewText:
First and foremost, let me say that this is a game where you will need to pay to support the game at some point if you want to really get into what others can do. However, it is never necessary to just play and support teammates and your factions. You can get enough free cards with just a couple of minimal purchases to allow you to do a few interesting things such as intantly repopulate an army on occassion or keep your production levels running high in your villages.

I first ran into Stronghold Kingdoms just after lauch. I had been a fan of the franchise for several years already. I had already played a few 'MMORTS' games already, though, and was a bit burned out on the type of gameplay necessary to keep from getting steamrolled, i.e. sleepless nights, missing work or school, constantly watching from your smartphone... well, you get the point. The change from the high competition to strong cooperation was such I actually felt let down and dropped the game after a few months. (I will note that I did not make a strong effort to find a faction or join a house in the glory race, and so I had missed out on a huge section of gameplay that would have kept me playing.0

I recently picked up SHK again and started playing and noticed some of the changes that had been made. I played a few weeks and noticed some of the core things weren't really different, though. If you don't join up with a faction/house, things are pretty boring. I should note that is unless you just decide to be the thorn in everyone's side, and of course, that has its own levels of excitement. I joined a house on the latest server, USA 2, and things are promising to be interesting.

The one big addition to the game I have really liked is the quests. For people completely new to the game, it gives some direction as to how to play and what to do. For all, it's extra rewards that help you get established in the game faster and something else to compete over. They start off easy and build up to the difficult or very time/resource intensive.

My final complaint about the game is that the honor cost of attacking smaller players can still be prohibitive. This is what gives the game its more laid back style, but makes it difficult to deal with the annoying players that deliberately don't level up and constantly harrass with cheap troops just to annoy those around them.

Overall, I give SHK a thumbs up as it can keep a properly-minded person entertained for hours and days at a time without requiring you to sit and stare at your avatar 100% of the time. For those easily addicted and like to micro-manage each minute: play at your risk.

reviewText:
First of all don't get fooled by my play time on this game. I normally play through the stand alone client and have 2 years of experience. Now taking about the game... i can honestly say this is one of the best mmorpg games i have ever played. Although the graphics look like it's from the late 1990s, the fact that this requires so much communication between players especially in wars, makes it so much addictive even without decent graphics.
It is free to play but as all f2p games are, there are special bonuses for people who pay. There is no premium account here, rather a premium token which grants the player several bonuses like research and building queues, auto trade, scout and recruit troops. These are generally in from of 7-day and 30-day tokens which can be bought but there are 2-day tokens which are given in the tutorial and some quests. The fact that free players can have these 2-day tokens from quests in multiple worlds makes them at level with the payers. Also another thing that is bought are cards. Now these give massive boost to almost everything in the game. Free players do gain cards by completing quests, but this is nowhere near the amount of cards bought by payers. This is where the games get very pay to win. A f2p player can easily get frustated at this and leave. But there is a way to carry on. A f2p player just needs to communicate with the payers and ask them for help. Most will gladly agree and also invite them to factions if the player is active. Now in a faction, different people gather together and can help each other out in times of need whether its war or building up. Lot of f2p players complain that payers can get their villages, castles and armies up in seconds with cards. This is true and very frustating for a f2p, but through communication and diplomacy, you can get resources to make the same. But the drawback is that it does take a lot of time. The fact that there is no limit to the amount of cards that a player can purchase is a very serious drawback to the game for f2p players. The only way to get round this is to leave pvp to carders and play the role of a supplier or monker to the fighters for f2p players. This creates the necessicity for lot of communication and that is one of the strong points in the game. In war, helping others with resources and monking(influencing) requires so much communication, that one is able to lose sleep! However the chat system is pretty flawed and people don't use the mail syestem that much because it takes too much time. That's why people use 3rd party programs like teamspeak and skype to communicate.
You can have many villages and that too with of different types which grant special resources, research different technologies, create different armies, battle the AI, wolves and other players. The main goal is to win the age and you can only do that if you are in a faction/house. So this is not a solo game and requires teamwork. It is possible to succed as a f2p player if you know the game mechanics very well and communicate with others, but if not then you can get very bored easily. The most inetersting part comes when war takes place, as you feel the urge to be online almost all the time lest your villages get destroyed by the enemy and also to take them out while they are offline! And as stated before this requires huge amounts of communication which can help us create new friends. The faction and house is literally like a family when you play for long with them.
Altogether this is a great free to play game but not close to the best. If you can spend some cash or dedicate enough time this will really become very addictive :) I would recommend this to others who want to play strategy games and have a lot of patience.

With regards
Guardian002
(currently active in usa2)

reviewText:
A fun and easy game to get into, new players will soon find themselves immersed in a world far more complex than it's user-friendly interface would have them believe. Most tasks don't feel like chores, and completing any task or quest leaves one feeling rather accomplished.  Friends and allies are easy to find, and even if one invests minimal time into this game, they will find themselves rising through the ranks far faster than they may have anticipated.  There are challenges ahead, mostly earned by facing down other players, but it is easy enough to rise to the task.

All players have within them a ruler struggling to break free.  Do you have what it takes?

Come, join us, and show us your true mettle.

reviewText: The game is on the whole well balanced.  I do however think that ther eshould be a limit on the amount an individual user can spend per month since cards have such a high impact. Keep up the good work.  Looking forward to crusader II.

reviewText: Great Game!  It is challenging on many different levels, and requires multi-strategy.  You dont just build your villages you build and maintain castles.  At the same time, you research, trade, and cultivate faith points to make sure you have enough to ID when needed, and to use them to fight.  Your villages can be destroyed with a well timed attack or multiple attacks timed up, so there is strong impetus to learn how to defend well.  By playing with a faction and ultimately a house, you strive for glory, learn how to fight as a team, and end up joining communities online of like minded people; so in effect it becomes a very social game.  One issue is that certain individuals (I wont name any Russians names) multi account, and because they spend alot of money firefly allows it, and they dominate certain servers, Europe server being one.  Overall though, very good game!\n\nBrethranus (in game name)

reviewText:
Stronghold Kingdoms is a dangerous game.  It is at least for me, as it is highly addictive.  I feel compulsed to play everyday, as there is always more to achieve.  I have noted several reviews which complain about card play and buying cards.  I have gotten strong in the game by investing time, not money.  I did buy cards to move from three free cards a week to 14 cards a week.  But I am keeping most of my cards for a future game . . . (evil laugh).  I do find the premium token useful, mostly when I am building a new town.

If you want to see come check me out in USA1.  For I am:
Dan Longshanks

reviewText: I love this game even though it is a pay to play.     Even if you only have ten bucks a month to spend on it I would recommend it.  (if you are into an in depth long term strategy MMO.)        I do wish they used a little more with the landscape like in the old ones.    Also,  the troops tend to do stupid things sometimes.    I wish you could put rally points for the troops to go to,  when they get there they could proceed to the next one. (maybe as an advanced option.)       Game is to reliant on Faith Points.   There is a domination world that removed them completely but it's not a long term game.       Over lots of fun in my opinion if you have the time and a little money.\n\nNastyTactics815

reviewText: The best military strategy game, Requiring diplomacy, cooperation, and great patients.  Its a game you can play as you are doing other things and other games.  The time it takes to do anything in this game allows one to perform 30mins or so of interactions and to check back in hours later.  So even though it takes time to do anything in the game its not a major time drain.  Some of the best game mechanics in a city builder and strategy game I have ever seen.  With many paths to victory including, monking, supplier, or fighter depending on how you prioritize your research.  Highly recommend this game, and it is the longest running game I have ever played.

reviewText:
I do recommend this game because of how in depth and captivating the gameplay can become. Start from nothing and quickly gather resources, build your village, build a castle to protect your village, climb the ranks,  and research new techonolgy to strengthen your empire. Join a guild to help out other players just starting, defend eachother from enemy attacks, attack the enemy head on and so much more. The number of possible tactics and strategies are endless. I personally enjoy foraging everything in site by researching scouts, their speed, and their carriyng capacity to maximize their effectiveness. It's a middle ages game taken to new heights. Oh, and one last thing... IT'S FREE TO PLAY!!!

Come join the fun and build your kingdom accross a variety of maps and worlds, THE FUN STARTS NOW!

Enjoy your game!

reviewText: A timeless era, miniaturized on screen, but certainly expansive in scope and scale. This is one of those games that you can pick away at, village by village, farm by farm, castle brick by brick.  Or, this is a game that you can get swept up in, by either trying to stay out of the eventual fighting by opposing Houses and Factions, or by jumping in headfirst to join the slugfest between hundreds of live opponents.\n\nSK asks for patience as you develop, perform missions, gather resources, and build your villages and castles.  Developing growing and successful villages, leading to resources used for castle building, can test even the most patient of players.  SK's game system admittedly offers those that can play cards" an advantage in this all-important economic progress aspect of the game
date: enabling players to accelerate the pace of their development through the use of in-game cards.  War fighting and other combat related aspects of the game can provide a similar challenge.  Attack a computer-generated target without proper resources and troops
recommended: and you risk a punishing war of attrition against an inanimate foe that constantly regenerates.  Attack a human player with a similar lack of war readiness
hoursPlayed: and you risk being annihilated by foe and potentially countless hordes of opportunistic foes alike.  Attack or counter-attack with good strength and patience-driven readiness
voteText: and the glory of a 2D face planting of your enemy is yours.\n\nSK is essentially a winner-take-all game
helpfulPercent: with a twist.  Players can attempt to stay neutral (my 10-year old son named his village "Be Nice to Neutrals" and has so far survived).  Or
votesHelpful: players can join a House and one of its many subsets (Factions) to wage either diplomacy and/or warfare on your enemies.  The game can seem unbalanced at times on the latter
votesTotal: as players seem to gravitate toward joining the strongest House out of fear of getting wiped off the map or shunned to the ash heap of Houses that are periodically eliminated as the game progresses.  SK game designers would be well served to add 2nd place
votesFunny: 3rd place (etcetera) awards to Houses (like mine) that seem to start the periodic map resets at a numeric disadvantage to the one or two Houses that are immediately in the lead.\n\nOverall
commentsCount: SK Is a solid game for those that want a 2D game that they can enjoy either semi-passively -- or quite aggressively.  It basically comes down to this:  What you put into it
column16: you tend to get out of it.  And
column17: as the game offers a very deep strategic experience
column18: if you are fortunate to join a House and Faction that is well connected (we use Raidcall to communicate in the House and Faction that I am in)
column19: SK can offer even some very enjoyable operational and tactical experiences as well.\n\nusername:  jazos"
column20: September 8, 2014

reviewText:
My favorite of all the MMOs I've tried. Consistently deep and fun, without ever feeling routine, bland, or mechanical. I don't know whether it's a pay-to-win game, as some claim, but it's certainly free to have a whole heap of fun.

At its heart, though, the game is still an MMO and suffers from the relentless need to continuously push ahead — a few consecutive busy days in real life can be hard to overcome in the game world, a situation which doesn't match my lifestyle very well, I'm afraid.

But if you enjoy MMOs, I highly recommend Stronghold Kingdoms. Shoot, you might even be able to talk me into getting back into it.

Stronghold Kingdoms is a dangerous game.  It is at least for me, as it is highly addictive.  I feel compulsed to play everyday, as there is always more to achieve.  I have noted several reviews which complain about card play and buying cards.  I have gotten strong in the game by investing time, not money.  I did buy cards to move from three free cards a week to 14 cards a week.  But I am keeping most of my cards for a future game . . . (evil laugh).  I do find the premium token useful, mostly when I am building a new town.

If you want to see come check me out in USA1.  For I am:
Dan Longshanks

reviewText: Stronghold Kingdoms is a multifaceted strategy game that gives you access to a friendly community of game players. It allows you to build and manage villages, go to war against the enemy or farm in total peace. I can spend hours communicating with my fellow faction members strategizing about where to move or whom to incapacitate with a directed monk. This game will bring you into a whole new realm of game play.  Enjoy. I have. And I hope to see you in my world having a banquet at my table.\n\nTrueNorth

reviewText:
Stronghold Kingdoms is a highly addictive game that allows me to burn some time at the end of the day. After working at my job and then doing work on masters courses, you just have to have something to do in order to change things up.

The best part about this game is that it brings the original Stronghold to an online type game. The Stronghold franchise has been one of my favorite for the past six to seven years and Kingdoms is a great addition to it. Another great part about this game is the ability to play it with other people and get to know them. I have played with doctors, actors, athletes, and many others, on this game and the ability to connect with others in a game that models after a favorite of mine for years is incredible.

I am still kinda sad that they got a few of the states wrong in the USA maps, but can live with Columbus not being the capital of Ohio and other things like that.

reviewText: This is a highly addicting game with tons of cool features. I really like how players play such a high role in the politics of this game and how thoughsands are involved in the decisions they make. I find it highly amusing that you can just be a regular guy playing a game but you can be in charge of a house of over 500 people. The geography of this game is well made and several times on the USA worlds I have been like wait I have been here in real life". You can build friendships through this game that last for years. I for one have met 4 people here who I now play other games as well as this game with them and we have been doing so for 3 years. 10/10 I love to play this game with my friends.\n\nnawatcrow20"

reviewText:
Overall, Stronghold Kingdoms is a great game but there are few things that make it less popular than other stronghold games I own. For instance, Stronghold Kingdoms has various researchs which need to been done in order to advance further in the game, and various other advantages for paying users who buy crowns. But, ultimately the game becomes very time consuming taking days and months on end to advance very far. Which results in the fact that many people leave the game, because for example you leave for about a week with everything being fine but return to find a mess and half your castle destory. (Happened to me, and a few friends.) Lastly, the factions and glory race part of the game leaves something to be desired since, as the ages progress in the game all factions and houses are reset to help things over. But such is not the case since, more often then not I have found getting into a house is challenging and the members of the former winning all are top rank and join the same house over again to win the next age.

Ultimately, I would recommend the game, but would advise avoiding it unless you like a high degree of user-interaction and waiting around.

EmperorElijah
Playing since September 2012

reviewText:
This is a game that I have grown to love and enjoy, I feel like I am in medival times having to make those tough descisions on what to research and what to build as well as keep my villagers happy. You will need to be patient, this game is meant to look after it self while you enjoy searching for a faction and house to join. I have been lucky enough to find such and flourish without much complication and I have been given useful advice by everyone in my faction. You will be involved in wars, you will have times where you need to adjust your village for better purpose and you will most certainly loose soldiers. The combat is fun to watch and NPC castles can be a challenge to those that wish to test themselves.

Overall it is a game that requires thought, patience and willingness to make alligences. A game for people who desire a chance to build an empire.

Auroran
